Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

glxVn1-zxsLW9p0ZQAw1FQ.text: One of the best meals of my life - I am not kidding - that is how fantastic this place is.  From the moment you walk in, the place is very attractive & buzzing - lots of activity going on.   Spectacular service awaits you here - we were a table of 8 & constantly had 3 people helping us. True professionalism that is missing in many restaurants.  We did the chef's tasting so the chef chose the apps & desserts & we got several kinds of steak & lobster to eat as our main.    The apps were shrimp cocktail, salads, prosciutto, & other things that I forgot but everything was fabulous.  SO HARD to not pig out during there apps!  For entree's we got 5 different kinds of steaks - all cut for us & every one of them were mouthwateringly delicious!  We also got lobster - lots of it.  We also got lots of sides - I ignored them - too much other good stuff to fill up on!  The desserts were all yummy as well!   The wine prices were also reasonable & not outrageous like the place next door.  Truly a spectacular experience & one I will never forget!!!!

WWNnjLzIxiEgl19UtMkL6w.text: 12.28.14 Now that I'm older and have no desire or energy to go clubbing when I'm in Vegas, I've found another way to blow my hard-earned cash. $$$$ restaurants definitely fit the mold. Unfortunately, Robuchon was booked up through the week, so plan B it was. OpenTable reservations were plentiful for Craftsteak, so this was nice and easy. We waited a bit to be seated. We waited a bit longer to get our drink orders in (highland fling for him, malbec for me). And even longer between courses. Service was spotty, to say the least. Portions, however, were generous. I'm glad we settled on sharing one appetizer (the lobster bisque), one protein each (short ribs for me, kobe skirt steak for him), and a side (shishito peppers). Lowlight: the lobster bisque was way over-seasoned, and didn't really signal a great start to the meal. yelp.com/biz_photos/tom-... Saving grace: both the short ribs and the skirt steak were cooked perfectly. The ribs came out steaming hot while the skirt steak was a tad cooler - perhaps was waiting for the other dish to be finished before being brought out all together. yelp.com/biz_photos/tom-... The shishito peppers were a good balance, but we could only finish half the plate given how large the meat dishes were. Overall: glad I checked this off my list, but no desire to return anytime soon. Total damage for two: $229

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. short ribs, skirt steak, and shishito peppers
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. lobster bisque

NagWebhB1oqQsdqliW6VeA.text: Pack Your Knives & Go!   I used to be a huge fan of Tom Colicchio & Top Chef back in its hay day, and I'm always a lil leary about celeb chefs who open up shop but given his snarky, critical ways on Top Chef I had higher hopes for his restaurant but my great expectations are rarely realized... The reviews I read prior to coming to Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak located in the MGM Grand Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas, NV are all over the charts. Read on for a fair, balanced & uncensored review...  The menu at Craftsteak is extensive, a la carte & expensive. There are a plethora of starters, sides, starches, veggies, varying types of steaks including both Domestic & A5 Japanese Wagyu, seafood & other meat options to choose if beef isn't your baby. There is also a vast offering of wine, liquor, fine bourbon & whiskey selection at Craftsteak.  First off, the complimentary bread at Craftsteak is called "Parker House Rolls," and they are these soft, traditional-style dinner rolls that are served in a cute, lil cast-iron muffin pan. The tops are buttered & they melt away in your mouth. I'm not one to typically write about or indulge in the free carbs let alone accept seconds, but shamefully I did! They reminded me of my mom's only betta! 6-gems for seducing me into eating the sinfully good carbs!   The sides here are a la carte & meant to be shared according to David my server. Portion-wise, you aren't getting Chicago steakhouse "shareable sides," where each side is enough to feed a family of 4. Rather, the sides here are enough for 2 small servings for 1 person or 1 serving split between 2 people.   I love mushrooms & Craftsteak has a gemtastic selection of different types of shrooms to choose from rather than just your standard sauteed portobello or button shrooms. I ordered the hen of the woods mushrooms. These shrooms are lil hearty/meaty clusters that are earthy & rich-tasting. You don't get a whole lot for $15, but I don't see them on many steakhouse menus, so they were worth it. Get them if you go here, 5-gems!  I also ordered a side of hand-cut french fries that had a smoked paprika & sherry vinegar seasoning on them. I don't normally order fries with steak but the seasoning profile sounded interestingly good, plus the rolls had me craving more carbs, aghh! I'm glad I did though cuz my intuition was right. These fries are bomb! The fries were hand-cut, soft & potatoey with crisp edges & was an awesome-tasting spice/flavor combo. Mr. Colicchio doesn't give you a whole lotta these guys for $12 but taste wise, 5-gems!   My protein: I special requested a 6 oz, center-cut, prime filet mignon off the menu. They don't have one listed on the menu, only a 10 oz size & I didn't want that big of a steak. I ordered my steak my usual way, medium-rare & it came out in a sizzlin' cast iron skillet with a small vidalia onion on the side. Temperature wise, my steak was prepared on point to a perfect medium-rare, but it didn't wow me for $70. The steak was good but the flavor was nothing extraordinary. It didn't melt in my mouth & I did see some fat laced in it, boo! This steak doesn't hold a candle to the steaks at either Gibson's or Chicago Cut, my 2 fave steakhouses in Chicago. But the steak was accurately prepared & cutely presented & overall good, so 3.5 gems!   For dessert, I chose the Chocolate Souffle & scoop of hazelnut chip ice cream ($15). It was a tiny, light, airy cake served in a lil ramekin alongside a tiny dollop of hazelnut chip ice cream. This is an ideal, happy ending if you want a chocolate-type dessert that's not too heavy or filling. It's not very big at all nor rich or overly sweet but is a top-notch, complementary-tasting duo.  Lastly, the ambience here is upscale, casual/dressy & I had my own reserved private, cool booth/table. Unfortunately, the service here left a bad taste in my mouth though. My server David started out strong, like he knew what he was doing, but then when we said give us a few minutes & come back, he took that as the green light to go MIA the remaining time. He was friendly the couple times we saw him but was lacking in the attentive department. Little does David know, patience is not my virtue, especially when I'm hungry! I abhor flagging down other wait staff to get refills, meals & bills! If I was Tom Colicchio, I would have you pack your knives & let you go. You definitely wouldn't make it waiting at a steakhouse in the Windy City. We expect high prices & great steaks but not service that is nearing shitty!  My whole meal was a gemlicious, high 4-gems, service was 2-gems & my entire rating=3+gems! In sum, if you want the best steaks & service head to the Midwest & go to almost any steakhouse in Chicago, IL, my top choices being Gibson's or Chicago Cut. If you wanna go to a celebrity-owned steakhouse that serves stellar, free dinner rolls & pricey, yummy sides from a lackadaisical waitstaff go to Craftsteak in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gem&#39;s dessert: Chocolate Soufflé &amp; scoop of hazlenut chip ice cream ($15): light, airy cake &amp; very tasty ice cream!
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of Hen of the Woods mushrooms ($15): earthy, meaty, rich, yes!
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of hand-cut french fries with smoked paprika &amp; sherry vinegar ($12): awesome flavor combo, 5 gems!

SiiM-RqAPYVyZNevM47uaw.text: When I learned that my husband would be attending CES in Las Vegas, I decided to join him for the sole purpose of eating at Craftsteak. I spent months drooling over the menu, scanning photos online, reading reviews, and planning what I would order. I have never been so excited for any meal in my life, as I was for this. It was everything I hoped it would be. The wait staff was polished, solicitous, and very knowledgeable. The atmosphere was elegant, warm, and a little playful, too. Eric, our food waiter, made sure to ask us what time constraints we might have. Our drinks waiter helped my husband and his brother find the perfect whiskey flights for their tastes. My husband savored his samples all evening long. My wine flight was luscious, and paired perfectly with each course. Before my first course, I indulged in the house rolls. While I didn't want to take up valuable real estate in my stomach with bread, I simply couldn't help myself from eating 2 of the delicious, buttery rolls. Yum! My first course was the Maine Lobster Bisque. It was rich, creamy, and delightful. I've never had tarragon before, and it was a delicious little adventure for my tastebuds. My main course was the Surf 'n Turf with Filet Mignon and lobster. The filet was divinely tender, and the lobster was beautifully rich. My original plan had been to order a Risotto. I have watched enough seasons of Top Chef to know that THIS would be the place for risotto. Sadly, it is a seasonal offering, and it was no longer on the menu. So I will have to wait for the chance to indulge in that delicacy. But I was in for a simply delightful treat. The GRITS! WHITE CORN GRITS, PROSCIUTTO, GRUYER! A. MA. ZING! I had trouble sharing those grits with the rest of my table. I could eat those every day, for the rest of my life. I wrapped up my meal with the Cinnamon Monkey Bread. A definite must. I make monkey bread every year for Christmas morning breakfast. I will have to step up my game, if I am to ever be satisfied with Christmas breakfast again. Hands-down, the most memorable and delicious dining experience of my life. Thank you, Craftsteak!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dinner rolls, Maine Lobster Bisque, White Corn Grits, Surf &#39;n Turf, Cinnamon Monkey Bread, wonderful waiter, Eric.
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. So excited to eat here! The cow finds my enthusiasm troubling...

HsjkpXZhDT6Db8M8pvm7pA.text: This is my new favorite Vegas meal. We went there on 8/13/16 and had a little wait to get seated (even with reservations) for our table of 4. We all got appetizers: prosciutto with peaches, Caesar salad, and two of us got the mozzarella. The Caesar salad was what was expected and the other 3 of us loved our choices. For entrees, we got the wagyu surf and turf, 16 oz NY strip, 10 oz filet and scallops. The scallops were amazing. Absolutely amazing. The other girls all loved theirs as well. For sides, we got corn, grits, potato puree, assorted mushrooms, and Maui onions. The potato puree was absolutely incredible, just like every other Yelp review says. I will dream about these!! For the first time ever, we were too stuffed for dessert but the monkey bread or peanut butter chocolate lava cake sounded incredible.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mozzarella to start the meal

Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Some assorted mushrooms (4 kinds), Maui onions, scallops (some of the best I&#39;ve ever had), and potato purée (indescribably good)!

kUlz2J0RxLjeMFbxnEH-Zg.text: I came here for my fathers birthday with a large party of 9 people.  This is a very traditional steakhouse restaurant with simple but delicious choices.  We started out with a dozen oysters, shrimp cocktail, and  sides like risotto and corn for the kids.  I only had the oysters but that was all I needed because it was so fresh and delicious. It was so delicious that we ordered a half more. One tip of warning is that the horseradish is really strong.  Next up was the main course which was the beef that everyone ordered. I had the domestic wagyu filet mignon...it was godly. Easily the tenderest beef I have had. It was like cutting into butter. Besides the meat we had an assortment of sides like potato puree, corn, asparagus, and cauliflower. Everything was cooked to perfection.   I enjoyed the service and am rice that was set it was created as a lively but intimate setting even in Vegas. There was a server for every different dish.  Overall rating:  Food and preparation: 5/5  Ambience: 5/5  Customer service: 5/5

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oysters, risotto, corn, spinach
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sides: asparagus, potato, mushroom, and more

QILDmI9nFPn0X43zJ_jO7g.text: On a recent visit to Las Vegas we decided to have a 5-star dinner. We wanted excellent food, excellent service, and an excellent environment. We decided on Steaks and chose Tom Colicchio's, more for the proximity to our rooms than anything else. Las Vegas has become a town of overpriced mediocrity, but Tom Coliccio's, while expensive delivered a fantastic experience.  We chose the chefs selection which consisted of a great selection of apps and sides, but the reasons you go to a steak house is not for the sides so let's talk steaks. We had the Wagyu Flank to start, it was a great piece of meat and carried a wonderfully rich flavor. Next was the Kobe Filet Minion, this was incredibly tender, soft, delicate and gentle on the pallet. Then we moved onto the Kobe New York. Let me say I have had my fair share of New York's, dry aged, Kobe, thick and thin, $10 to $100. The New York steak from Tom Colicchio's was cooked a perfect medium rare, it was season but ever so lightly to highlight but not overpower the steak. It was my favorite of the night and a steak I will not soon forget. It was clear that the kitchen had mastered their craft while using the best equipment for the task. The location in the MGM Grand is good but does not feel like like a traditional steak house, something I found myself missing a bit. This was soon forgotten when the steaks arrived. If you are on a budget this may not be the place for you.  But if you want a memorable meal, enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu Flank, Kobe Filet, Kobe New York!

LVJ_KATPBdsui6MmyD5rqA.text: Both my boyfriend and I thought this place was a great space and the service was amazing! We felt the food was average and not extremely special for the price point. We would most likely not make it a point to eat here again

Sx--eWOJkILW2cuvJaCmvw.text: The hubby and I came in for dinner the other night and enjoyed being stuffed to the brim. Since we couldn't decide between the Domestic Wagyu Ribeye and the Aged Bone-in Ribeye, we decided to get both.  Both ribeyes were excellent, but our favorite was definitely the Wagyu, the flavor is absolutely decadent. If we had not ordered the two ribeyes side by side, I would have also been thoroughly impressed with the aged ribeye as well.  Lobster Bisque - this is lobster bisque done right, I loved the chunks of lobster and the tarragon in the soup was an excellent touch  Potato Puree - you know this is not going to be you standard mashed potatoes just looking at it, it was rich and flavorful and the perfect side for the ribeyes  Our waiter was fantastic and a blast to talk to.  The only issue I had was with the hostess, we had a reservation but still ended up waiting for our table, even though a fourth of the restaurant was empty.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Perfect lobster bisque
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Potato puree
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aged bone in ribeye

ZiquKCaO7rFpt_ZE0K7wmQ.text: Holy amazing steak, Batman!!   I was here with a group of 72 people, so we had a private-ish area off of the main dining room. Our servers were on point. If water glasses got to low, someone was there instantly to refill. If wine got to low, same thing. Everyone was super friendly and attentive. It was amazing.   For appetizers, we had Beef Tar-Tar, Oysters, and two types of salad, plus rolls. The Beef Tar-Tar was delicious, and the salads were fresh and crisp. Our main course was a selection of Wagyu Skirt Steak, Filet Mignon, Lobster Tail, and another cut of steak that I'm currently blanking on, with sides of mashed potatoes, asparagus, mushrooms and spinach. It was all served family style so that everyone could try some of everything. I have never had such great pieces of steak...ever. The skirt steak was definitely the winner of the three cuts. The mashed potatoes were melt in your mouth amazing, and the asparagus was cooked to perfection. For dessert, it was a selection of ice creams, gelatos, apple crisp, and sweet potato cheesecake...all of which was out of this world delicious.   For anyone staying in Vegas and in need of a great steak, I highly recommend this place!!

4jWx43eXDhDBb7EW9iwJlw.text: Made a reservation on Open Table and got seated right away. We were staying at the MGM and decided to find a good dining establishment right here in the hotel for the convenience. CRAFTSTEAK did not disappoint!  Food:  1) Roasted Beet Salad $13: this dish was beautifully presented. My favorite part of this dish was the pickled egg that was dyed pink. The acid definitely brought out the sweetness in the beets.  2) Butternut squash soup $16: They bring out a soup bowl with pancetta lining the bottom of the bowl. Then they pour your butternut squash soup into your bowl. The soup was creamy and delicious.  3) Wagyu Skirt Steak $78: Heeding the recommendations of several Yelp reviews, I landed on the Wagyu Skirt steak. I love skirt steak because you can really taste the beefiness. What made this skirt steak so special was that not only was the flavor on point, it was SOOO tender! I usually have problems chewing on beef because of some dental issues but with this steak, there were no issues at all. I was able to savor every bite and enjoy it. This was the best skirt steak I have ever tried.  4) Angus Rib Eye $55: a nice hunk of beef! I usually get rib eye whenever I can but I was happy that my partner ordered this. It was meaty and fatty, just how a rib eye should be.  5) Our sides approx $13 each: maui onion, yukon gold puree, prosciutto butternut risotto: we enjoyed each of the sides that we ordered.   6) Monkeybread with banana ice cream $15: It didn't take much convincing to order this dessert. Wish it came with more ice cream though!  Total cost of dinner came out to about $300 after tip. We definitely had food leftover and packaged it up to go. It was STILL very tasty the next day!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-1XRl7gZKoH0mQMIdQRSYQ.text: Meat! Meat! Meat!  Now I am ruined on delicious steaky bits for the next few months, at least! Or until the memory of the food from here fades. I had dined at Colicchio and Son's on our last visit to NY and it was amazing. The service was out of this world. So naturally, I wanted to try this place out when we were in Vegas.  Our server was lovely. She recommended the chefs tasting menu and the mid level wine pairing, so that's what we went with. Good lord, it was a ton of food. You need to come hungry. Wave after wave of food hit the table and everything was seasoned well, bright, full of flavor and worked well together. My favorites were the lobster bisque served in a adorable little pot, the fingerling potatoes, the mushroom medley, the prosciutto, and a lovely persian cucumber salad with lots of crunchy veggies.  Beware of the little rolls they bring out that are covered in butter and sprinkled with salt. They are addictive and you will have stuffed 3 in your mouth before you know what happened.  We did the wagyu beef and shared the sirloin and the ribeye. It was heaven. I'm kind of sad thinking about it right now because the MGM is so far from Dallas.  For dessert I was too full to do anything but graze. That being said, I did manage to get a few bites of the monkey bread with banana ice cream. It's sinful. The chocolate mousse comes with adorable little cow cookies and the fruit plate was vibrant and a nice light treat.   Looking around the restaurant, they have all of these cow paintings done in a funky head shot style.  I loved them. It's very open inside, but the low lighting and atmosphere still leans towards romantic. I love the chairs in the front bar area - think leather arm chairs with small tables so you lounge in comfort while you wait.   I can't wait to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monkey bread and banana ice cream
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chocolate mousse and animal crackers
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desserts that came with family style dinner

dOzaMDNKHismtgFsadeJtg.text: First time visit this steak house  Food was very good a little overpriced like everything else in Vegas  But have to mention skirt stake was one of the best I ever tried

oMYRKrP1VXnPY314bTWKSQ.text: The steaks are great. The menu is amazing. The A5 was well worth the flavor and the sides are great. Free bread to start is so good. Only reason they get a 4 is the drinks are slow to come and they changed the dessert menu. Bring back the chocolate lava cake.

XtbxXMEIgojc-9sd2VSMQg.text: Huge portion of lobster bisque. Delicious with huge chunks of lobster. Yum!  Also had the stuffed squid... which was interesting... not my fav. Pan seared scallops were cooked perfectly. I got the hanger steak which had great flavor and thin. just the way I liked it. Also got the ribeye steak.. it was delicious.  Got the lemon tart and the earl grey ice cream (my fav!) for dessert and they were both yummy.  Great ambiance for date night. Must go!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Earl Grey ice cream
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lemon tart
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ribeye steak

2RpUYPK5cc-FZjCbdjM1Dw.text: We really enjoyed our night out here. I had the wagyu skirt steak and it was really delicious. I would definitely get it again. The heirloom tomato salad was so fresh, ripe and colorful. I've had heirloom salads before, but this was just perfect. That tomato salad is what earned the 5th star here. I can't say enough about it!!  The wine list and cocktail menu comes on an iPad. Frankly, I thought it was a little distracting, especially in the dimly lit restaurant. I think a paper list would have been sufficient.  Our servers were excellent, which you expect for the price you'll pay at a place like this.  Here's a little tip, especially if you're staying at the Signature. You will get a good amount of food here, and it is all very rich. Don't be bashful about getting the leftovers boxed up. They make for easy reheating and an excellent breakfast in the morning! Just call housekeeping from your room to bring you a skillet and some utensils.

9qtETMTQn553kaF1fPUBaA.text: The food literally melted in my mouth!  EVERYTHING was Ono!  The service was excellent!  No wait to be seated even though they lost our reservation TWICE! . Would come back again just for this food.

1Irh7m8AklpIvU3IRZMfjw.text: Impeccable service at Craftsteak really gave the 5th star for the rating. I'd actually rate the food 4.5. It was an easy dining experience, and they seated us exactly on time. I'm a HUGE fan of Tom Colicchio, so I had high expectations.   I came here with my family for my birthday. The hostess was sweet and inviting, unlike a lot of Vegas airheaded hostesses that work on the Strip. From the moment we sat down, our server was warm and friendly.   The lobster bisque was dare I say... too flavorful. I suppose if you love an intense seafood flavor, go for it. The butternut squash was a better pick, and less rich because you are going to get an EXTREMELY rich second course! The wagyu skirt steak was amazing, and exactly what I expected, buttery and filled with flavor. Unfortunately by the second course I was already extremely full. The rissotto was well done, a little too mac-n-cheesy though. The complimentary birthday dessert was a nice touch in the end.   But still... I don't know if Tom Colicchio had any say in the staffing, but the service was truly impeccable, probably the best I've ever had ANYWHERE.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lobster bisque
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu Skirt steak

QD4ocT6Mjv0eNseP4HKirQ.text: Just ok. For the price it was just ok. So 2 stars for value. Wagyu tartar was ok. We had a salad with bacon and blue cheese that was not good. The short ribs tasted more like pot roast.

ky7c8Ml3LplhMMBoT6d6fg.text: Tom, this was a hard decision to make. You left me at a 3.5 but since yelp saved you with a 4. Meat? Delicious. We both had the American wagyu to celebrate and my god, that skirt was the best compromise of quality and price ever. Fantastic at every bite, you could feel the marbled fat melt into tender, buttery meat. Foodgasm that brough silence to the table. The ribeye (which was double the price) was delicious but lost out some of it's flavor due to the fact that it was just sooooo thick. That cut was close to 3 inches thick and made it hard to be a consistent medium all around.   Mussels were good although I wish there was spoons to taste the rich wine broth. The risotto we ordered as a side went untouched once the steak got here- flavorful and buttery but forgettable even with chunks of bacon inside.   The service was pretty perfunctory, it wasn't that they didn't try to stop by but it felt rushed and a little insincere since there were just so many other tables they had to pay attention to. There was also a fly that kept visiting our table- when you're dropping over $300 on a meal, you shouldn't be waving flies away.   The atmosphere and logistics was what failed the most here though. The LA Craft is romantic, with beautiful layout, quiet atmosphere and amazing service. The tables here are so close, I had to tuck my purse in close next to me so it wouldn't touch the man in the booth next to me. You had trouble getting in and out of inside seats for fear you would brush up against people's dinner plates. The worse were the lounge style dinner tables right out by the front. Total failure of keeping that upscale feel when you feel like you're being packed in like money sardines. If they could give me the LA feel with that delicious wagyu, I'm all Tom's.

kMobUViR-b2SHyfLRwA3Zg.text: Absolutely delicious. I had the free range chicken and my bf had the new York steak. We had a few sides, if you are interested in trying different sides, ask for half portions :) for half the price! I definitely recommend the risotto and the mushrooms assortment.

OTXx5ZjOGw6TcJslstWGqQ.text: Excellent service....awesome food... totally worth the price, which was less expensive than some of the other "Star chef" steakhouses I've been to in Vegas. I will definitely go back!

9IPMskb-UJuk0pMVzuD34w.text: I was taking my wife to Vegas for her birthday and after reading the reviews I decided to give CSH a try The long and short of it , not one of the top 50 places I have been , my bone in steak was very tough and so was her fillet . The lobster was good  and the asparagus was way over cooked. The wait staff was good at first but we had to wait over twenty minutes to get our check. Wish I had just gone to S & W as planned .

jXQH29c2mxPHgsnS86yjAg.text: Went there on 8/28/2016.  In one sentence, I thought it was very good, but but a few things could be improved imo. First off, I'll mention that the website doesn't list any price. In this day and age this hard to justify.  I was by myself. They sat me at a table where on one side is a chair, and the other side is a couch. I sat on the couch, to find that is was actually uncomfortable: kinda too deep, with no good back support). Sitting on the chair meant facing a white wall, so I sucked it up and stayed on the couch. Take those couches away Tom, they're terrible.  To begin I had the heirloom tomato salad. Just an array of heirloom tomatoes with olive oil. That was pretty good.  I ordered the domestic ribeye wagyu. It was phenomenal and cook perfectly.  The first side I had was the mushroom assortment. It was perfect with the steak.  The second side was the peppers and onions. That was pretty disappointing. I guess I expected roasted peppers, but I got these super crunchy slides of pepper. Crunchy because of the skin, which isn't great. There wasn't much onion to found in that dish.  Another problem I had were the portion sizes. They're way too big. The heirloom tomato salad was supposed to be an appetizer, it actually was a meal in itself. I had to stop halfway so I could enjoy the main course later. The sides were also enormous. Combined with a 14oz boneless ribeye steak, this is truly beyond my capacity (and I'm overweight, I can take a lot). I managed to finish the steak but nothing else.  Lastly I took the Duckhorn Vineyards wine pairing option, for $75. It's basically 3 reds (two cabs and a merlot). I think it was overpriced. The first wine was Decoy cabernet sauvignon, that was a rough wine. The other wines were better but nothing spectacular. Finally I wish the sommelier would have shared his tasting notes with me.  Service was excellent.  So overall pretty good but there's work to do. If the restaurant was somewhere else than Las Vegas I would have given it 4 stars, but Vegas has tons of amazing food options within a small radius so it takes a lot to stand out.

pWbNwr6nEzdWFs5HiEbCEw.text: Not much worse than getting food poisoning at a $$$$ restaurant. Thanks, Tom.  Although I had anticipated some sort of Vegas misadventure involving me throwing up every hour while suffering through immense feelings of regret and misery, I certainly didn't expect being bed-ridden in my hotel room as a result of eating a bad cut of steak.  Food was okay upon dining, but please, Tom Colicchio, let me decide how I want to lament a day consisting of my head being stuck down a garbage can.

wgrqs4NjcOw1ODa-_hbrQg.text: Under normal circumstances, I am against reviewing if you didn't dine. However, making me wait 30 minutes (with a reservation mind you) is not acceptable in my book. Telling me you're checking on my table only to never come back and disappear? Strike 2.  Unprofessional and totally unexpected for a restaurant of four dollar signs.   No worries, I know how to play the disappearing act as well.   Maybe you'll get your $$$$hit together and make it up to me one day.

dE8Ul7vR6LUvehL-0OUG1Q.text: My husband and I have dined at this restaurant twice prior to this visit and had such a great experience that we decided to return for our 14th anniversary. When we arrived at the podium to check in for our reservation, the hostess confirmed that we were return guests celebrating our anniversary. We were shown to a table and requested a booth. The hostess said she'd need to speak with her manager and she'd return shortly. Upon her return she stated that the booth's were reserved for larger parties. When I inquired about the several booths occupied by couples, she said that her manager specified that booths are for larger parties of 4. We again requested a booth from the hostess manager, explaining that it was our anniversary and again shown to another table, not a booth. We proceeded to order martini's and a bottle of wine for later. The martini's and wine were excellent, however once we finished the martini's the glasses sat on our table for a good 10 minutes after we had finished them. I know what you're thinking, that I am being overly sensitive but you have to keep in mind that we were sat at a 2 top table that was somewhat small and with all of the other dishes, glasses and cutlery, the space on this table was limited. We received a tasty lobster salad and proceeded to order the T-Bone steak and risotto to share. When the steak arrived it seemed smaller than 22 ounces and it was cold, literally cold. For $58 we expected the steak to be warm if not hot. The risotto temperature was double the temperature of the steak. Also, the Filet Mignon portion of the steak was at most 3 ounces of edible meat besides the fat. The New York portion was about 7 ounces of edible meat. Needless to say, when we told the waiter that the steak was cold, instead of removing it from the table he walked away and didn't return for about another 8 minutes. The manager came by to confirm the temperature of the steak and proceeded to remove the steak along with the plates. Pre-bussing was atrocious, at one point I had to stop staff passing by to request the removal of glass wear and plates. A new steak finally returned after 25 more minutes and was still small portions and luke warm to say the least. While we attempted to eat our new steak, we had at least 5 staff members ask how everything was within a matter of about 5 minutes. Every time we attempted to take a bite, there was someone hovering over the table, making sure everything was okay. Needless to say, they deducted the steak from our bill and offered some crazy monkey bread desert as a token for our anniversary. When we left the restaurant I again noticed 2 booths with 2 people sat which was again super annoying at this point. When I pointed out to the same hostess the 2 booths with 2 people sat, she reiterated that her manager said to extend the explanation that only larger parties are eligible to be sat at a booth. I again spoke to the manager again, whom was Christopher explaining that the hostess said that the manager stated that only larger parties are eligible for a booth, he said yes, I told her to say that. When I again pointed out the 2 tables with 2 people as well as the several booths sat with couples when we arrived, the manager said those people requested a booth. I felt like I was taking crazy pills. Christopher offered his card to email him when we come back and we left the card on the table. The food during this visit was mediocre to say the least. If we return to Craft Steakhouse, it will simply be for the martini's and possibly appetizers, not for the Steak. I truly hope whoevers reading this review has better luck with this restaurant.

tW1BQAaS3bTdMiMLodoVfw.text: There is stiff competition in Las Vegas for exceptional restaurants, and despite the crazy long walk back into the district of the MGM Grand, it was one of my all time favorite restaurants.  1. Unlike many restaurants in Vegas, our reservation meant something and we were instantly seated, where a server was already waiting for us at our table. 2. Very knowledgable about wine pairings and let my husband try a few to get just the right one.  3. Plenty of space, so it still felt intimate, yet you could still enjoy the cozy yet modern decor (Edison lights hanging, are my favorite) 4. Food was timed perfectly between courses. 5. My sea bass and his waygu filet were sensational, a party for your mouth. We had sugar snap peas and au gratin potatoes, which I am pretty sure we both wanted to lick the bowls. 6. Superior service the whole way through the meal and created a very special night out for us!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sea Bass, and yes that is bacon that looks like an @!

dDH2yC-vR0voDwafQF23JQ.text: The evening started off so promising...  The shellfish sampler appetizer was excellent.  The dinner rolls were terrific.  The ambiance was great.  The waiter was charming.  This is the extent of nice things I have to say about Craftsteak.  The waiter was a cool guy, but pretty forgetful.  This concerned me, as he was the type who didn't write your order down.  We had a table of 7.  I knew there would be food casualties in this dinner.  My T-Bone was ordered rare and came out medium.  I'm not the type to return food, but I kinda wanted to at this price.  But it was so late in the evening and I was so hungry...plus, the group I was with are the types to wait until everyone has their food, no exceptions. So I dealt with it.  On top of the off preparation, the steak itself was very tough... not just because it was medium.  It was difficult to cut.  I have no problem spending $57 on a steak, because it is more often than not a success.  This wasn't.  It was abysmal.  My other half enjoyed his steak more than I did, but wasn't really impressed by it the way a $60 steak should be.  One last thing about the food:  All of the sides, from the vegetables to the potatoes and so on, were unbelievably salty.  Getting to the end of them proved impossible because we're talking unappetizing levels of saltiness.  The other folks at the table said they enjoyed their entrees.  I don't know, though, because few plates were left clean... some not even half consumed.  The member of our party who had recommended we go to Craftsteak had said it was his absolute most favorite steakhouse anywhere.  When he got his meal, he said it was the best steak he had ever had.  He and I had ordered the same thing.  Maybe he'd had more to drink than I did.  Service was very slow... nearly 3 hours for dinner, and it wasn't that type of dinner.  Staff was attentive and great, but sluggish.  Too many other awesome places, let alone steakhouses, in Vegas to recommend this place or ever visit it again.  Factor in the cost of two cab rides to-and-from the MGM for our party... I'd call Craftsteak a bust.

11YE0rDmdZyhDgJRdtyLrA.text: We went to Craftsteak for my birthday, and it did not disappoint. As many yelpers note, the rolls are buttery and hot.  They are serious, try not to fill up on them, but I think you will.  It's okay, happens to the best of us.  They are big league carbs.  My wife ordered the heirloom tomatoes appetizer, and we had an unfortunate incident.  The server spilled them down my wife's back, and she was wearing a white shirt, so it was beyond noticeable.  But, the manager couldn't have been more friendly about it.  She quickly offered to pay for the dry cleaning and of course replaced the dish, gratis.  So, although that was annoying, accidents happen and they handled it excellently.  The prosciutto appetizer was a table favorite, as were the shrimp.  My steak was fantastic, a big fat ribeye (if you read any of my other reviews, you will notice a pattern in my choice of steak).  Textbook medium rare  The wine list is very solid, but it's expensive.  But, if you are eating at Craftsteak, you probably weren't looking for value menu pricing.  Definitely good for a special occasion.

_BTo1tvtDwRQ1S8P1lmEpw.text: The Service: The ordering experience was definitely off. Too many waiters for one table didn't make for a great experience...communication breakdowns for sure. There was a big mistake with our $310 steak, so we had to send it back and it made the dinner completely out of sync.  We ended up with 2 sides at the table with no main dish.   The Food: The ware frisee salad had SOOO much blue cheese that it over powered the entire salad and paired with bacon made the whole thing really salty. The brussels sprouts were also too salty. The lobster bisque and the mashed potatoes were very tasty and both had  really nice texture. We ordered the A5 Wagyu filet and requested med-rare +. It definitely didn't come out med-rare +, but it was still quite delicious.   Overall: This restaurant fell WAY below my expectations and was a major disappointment.

ezvZ7almDmWPNyd_ruWQpA.text: There's not much else that can probably be said about this place. The food is amazing - you can tell that attention has been paid in selecting every ingredient.  Skip the rolls.  They look great in the photos and in person, but there's nothing special about them.   We opted for the tasting menu for two - one with the wine pairing.  Typical wine pairings offer one glass with each course.  I cannot remember how many times they brought refills in the same course!  With the tasting menu we each had a cup of lobster bisque, three salads, two cuts of steak, three sides (one starch, two veg) and four desserts!  Entirely too much food - not complaining, but even coming in fairly hungry, we still didn't put a dent in half of it!  The two standouts of this meal? The pistachio gelatto and peach sorbet pairing and the service.  (Don't get me wrong, the lobster bisque, salads, meats and sides were phenomenal!!  Oh and I can't forget the FOUR desserts we were given!!)  But we literally sat here for almost 5 hours eating, talking and drinking and the only thing we finished were our drinks and the gelatto/sorbet!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted butternut squash
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Domestic Wagyu strip - just thick and juicy!!
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Domestic wagyu filet - perfectly charred medium steak!

F8D_Wryrdv3fSx6sSa9xqQ.text: Meh. The standout in this meal was the service - everything was expertly coordinated and timed well. The food was a let down. My filet lacked flavor and was chewy and unevenly cooked. The potato puree was gummy and bland, and the risotto was overpowered by the flavor of prosciutto. Chef, if you're reading: it would have been great to have that delicious prosciutto crumbled on top, but I got big, chewy pieces that didn't sit well. On a high note, we loved the kale and lobster bisque. Both were full of flavor.   Overall, we had better steak at Old Homestead in Caesar's Palace.

-0BUkbrM8MYk-PiY28fJQw.text: We decided to come here and see if Tom's restaurant lives up to his reputation as top chef head judge.  He didn't disappoint!  We decided to go for gold and get the A5 Japanese Wagyu meal for two.  The Frisee salad was amazing!  It tasted like salad carbornara; rich, eggy, with just the right amount of bleu cheese and bacon.  The filet mignon and new york strip were an experience like no other.  They literally melt in your mouth!  The assorted mushrooms were also amazing.  We learned about a new mushroom, hen of the woods, that paired perfectly with the steak.  Finally, all the desserts were amazing.  Even though I'm not a huge fan of bread pudding, I couldn't stop eating the brioche bread pudding with apple pie ice cream.  I have to say something about the level of service.  They found the perfect balance of servicing us but not being intrusive.  Everyone was personable and courteous.  It's clear they all love working there and they did their best to make sure we felt right at home.  It was fairly quiet in our booth; perfect for a romantic meal.  If you're looking for a once in a lifetime steak experience, I highly recommend coming here!

2b2vefgsE8z275qUcAS3WQ.text: I would come back here, but only for their Diver Sea Scallops.  Those were good!  I liked cutting up the scallops into tiny pieces so that I could have it with the fennel and cream sauce it came with.  The dish came with about five pieces, but I could have easily had two orders of this dish.  The bread and butter that came before our meal was average.  Slightly salted, and super buttered.    I will confess to having two-three of these :D  I can't really comment on the rest of the food here.  Although, the other members of my party did not rate this restaurant to highly :)

UpAxMxpkXW5_sIXlT7yhTw.text: My experience at Craftsteak was the worst I have had at an upscale steakhouse. It had nothing to do with the service, because the service was fine. It was the food that made my visit unpleasant.   The meal started off with rolls being served. They looked like Hawaiian roles, but not as sweet...and not as good.   Next was the main course. I ordered the bone in rib-eye and a side of the gratin potatoes. I asked for my steak to be medium-well, and it came out looking charred to a crisp. The server even said "rib-eye well...errrrr...medium-well" as he presented the plate to me. I immediately cut into the steak to see that the inside was slightly red, and it was just the outside that was extra crispy. Most of the steak tasted OK, but there were parts where it was so over cooked that it reminded me of eating a burnt marshmallow. It had that texture of being burnt to a bubbling state. I ate as much of the steak as I could, and tried to avoid as much of the burnt areas as possible.   The gratin potatoes were good, but nothing special. They came out hot, and the serving size was pretty good.   About a hour after I finished eating at Craftsteak, I had a terrible stomach ache. Granted, I had been in Vegas for a couple of days and my stomach was churning a bit from all of the buffets and drinks...but this was a different type of pain. It felt like I had a 16 pound bowling ball dropped on my stomach, and the feeling was with me ALL night. I will not be eating here again. The prices are astronomical for the experience and the sub par food. There are just so many steakhouses in Vegas that it is not worth it to tolerate a bad one.

opakenOacZm7RwdmsgL4Hw.text: The 'experience' of the restaurant was quite good. Interior and setting, etc. The waiter was great at the start, but after his first check-in after we got our main courses he sort of disappeared. When we ordered wine I told them who would be drinking it, but the wait staff (not our main waiter) still went to each and every person asking if they wanted wine, each of them needing to decline. And... hey it's not a big deal but it made for a somewhat awkward situation. Considering experiences at similar style restaurants, of similar reputation, I just would've expected a more attentive staff. At another point people's glasses had near emptied and I began to refill them. A server rushed over and actually wrestled the bottle from my hand mid-pour. It was bizarre.  The real issues, unfortunately, came with the food. Started with the Lobster Bisque which was ok. The Lobster was overdone and tough, but the soup itself was quite nice. I think the whole herbs they throw in are a bit much, they kind of stuck to my teeth as I was trying to enjoy a rather luxurious and pure soup.  On to the steaks! I had the New York, which, hey it's a standard New York strip and so I don't expect anything insane, but it was cold when it arrived and just wasn't as good as I would have expected. My girlfriend got the rather pricey Wagyu skirt on recommendation of the waiter as the best steak they have. It came rarer than ordered, and I tried a couple pieces, it just was not a great piece of beef. Luckily she liked the mashed potatoes. By contrast a nice but local hole in the wall near our home is one of her favorite steaks, also a skirt!, and for about a third of the price. I was ok with my steak, but she was just really sad about hers. I don't really care about me, but her not enjoying a meal breaks my heart.  Later on that night and the next day a lot of people were saying, "But their side items are so awesome!" And so we were joking for a while that it should be called Craftsides, but honestly ... the sides just weren't that good. The Robuchon style mash, sure, anything with that much butter is going to be good, but then I tried the orange colored, gloppy, Elmers glue-infused risotto. Amazingly it was the worst risotto I've had in my entire life. I was blown away how bad it was. All the other sides were good, but you know, pretty standard stuff.  It was a Sunday, it wasn't very busy, but the waiter never really came back (although he was great while he was there!), and when someone came to clear our plates a server asked if my girlfriend was done with her steak, and with 90% of the steak intact I sort of leaned in and said "She didn't really like it..." and he said ok and walked away with it. I didn't really care to cause a fuss in front of our group of friends, but at that point he really should have let our waiter know. I could have been forceful and really demanded her steak and the embarrassing risotto be stricken from the record, but we just wanted to leave and forget about it and go out and have fun. I wish I had said something now, of course, being a few hundred dollars poorer and nothing good to show for it, but anyway... Luckily we had good friends with us and we still had a good night.  I unfortunately can't recommend this restaurant to anyone.

2NQdJuHsUyqNJIr_gAEldA.text: After reading great reviews, we opted to come here.  We were definitely not WOW'd at the food and even disappointed a steakhouse would have such dull crappy steak knives!  Get better utensils, please, Chef Tom.  The service was alright but the food on the other hand, was disappointing!  We had intended to order the wagyu tasting menu but our waiter could not explain to us what was on the tasting and instead confused the heck out of us.   Starters: He ordered the quail and I ordered the foie gras.  The two little pieces of quail were nicely seasoned and tender but certainly did not blow us away. However, the foie gras was delicious.  The sweet candied kumquat accompanying the savory sauce created a perfect harmony with the foie gras.  We really enjoyed it.  Then...we waited for twenty minutes between our starters and main dish which really was a bit longer than we'd liked!  Entrees: I ordered the American Kobe filet mignon which was a HUGE disappointment.  I had requested for medium rare but the steak was cooked a bit more medium than I had liked.  Not to mention, the heavy handed seasoning defiled the filet.  The "hint" of blue cheese seared into the steak overpowered the tender cut and detracted from the meat.  He ordered the "regular" rib eye which was half the price of my American Kobe and it was DELICIOUS!  I don't ever regret ordering anything but boy did I absolutely wish I had ordered the rib eye too!  It was the one redeeming part of the meal thus far.  Side dishes: The Jerusalem artichokes were absolutely delicious (lots of fiber too!) It was cubed and reminded me of "country fries".  It was well seasoned and absolutely not oily at all.  It had great texture and the flavor was satisfying.    The Tuscan kale and smoked bacon, on the other hand, was way too salty.  We had to say something about it, and the waiter indicated that this is the response they often get when this dish is on the menu.  They took it off our bill and brought  us a different sauteed vegetable.  They explained that the smoke bacon adds the salt to the dish but as the kale sits and the sauce reduces, the overall dish becomes saltier.  YIKES, disappointing.  Dessert: I ordered the panna cotta which was an extremely sophisticated, or as my honey puts it, "adult" dessert.  The panna cotta is infused with jasmine. Think of the panna cotta as a delivery mechanism for the jasmine flavor. The texture adds interest.  When tasted by itself the scent of jasmine is very strong which I enjoyed but he thought was too strong.  The panna cotta sits on a macaroon and when eaten together, it is a perfect contrast of chewy and creamy (not milky tho) and the floral scent adds to the overall experience.  The serving plate is drizzled with honey and thinly sliced asian pears accompanies the dessert.  There was a lot of components and maybe even a bit too much going on, but I liked it.    He had ice cream which he called "kiddy dessert" - simple but excellent.  Excluding alcohol, our bill was $270, which in absolute terms isn't expensive per se, but in terms of the value we were expecting, it wasn't really worth it!    At over $110, the American Kobe filet was a BIG disappointment. At $24, the foie gras, although tasty, was a really small portion for the price.  The kale was just overall salty and blah.    I really wanted to like this place more.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. great panna cotta! DESSERT...YUM

f1By0wQTRd2R-LkhmytVtQ.text: Being a fan of Top Chef, vising Craftsteak was must on our trip to vegas! We didnt have a reservation, but were able to get seated on a cute table right by the bar. It was alittle nicer than being in the inside hall, since the lighting seemed to be brighter outside.   The atmosphere of the restaruant is very nice.. it is very calm but very professional at the same time. We started our order with Lobster Bisque. This is a must get if you have never tried it..or a fan or lobster. It taste like... wow did you melt the shell inside it too?? that is how deep and strong the flavor of the lobster is. They mean business when it comes to getting the flavor. I loved the soup! Foie Gras was also delicious, cooked very nicely and it went well with the Kumquat. The potato guratin was a little heavy, but it went well with everything.  The main course the meat... i had the Filet Mignon, which was cooked very nice, medium rare just the way i like it. Perhaps it was not the best piece of steak that I had, but none the less it was yummy!  I also have to rave about their bread! Talk about coming straight from the oven! The outside was crispy and the inside was fluffy! I think the bread was also the highlight of the evening!!

ilJvtB9ezyHggQvjtsmoLg.text: Boring and overpriced. $840 for three people. We had wagyu filet mignon, ribeye, and NY strip. Couldn't tell the difference from wagyu to regular prime cuts. Sides are boring. There is no wow factor here. Purre'd mashed potatoes, Brussels sprouts, and asparagus all cooked like every other steakhouse. I should have known better steakhouses do not try hard. There is zero creativity in this place. Poured our own wine every single time. Service was okay. I might be biased because I don't think grilled beef is worthy of high ratings.  Just boring for a wow factor bill.

A9F77Rlk6bk9XxJbKbLLdw.text: Solid meal. Service was almost impeccable.   I took my husband here for his 30th birthday. What better place to take a dude than to a steak house right? RIGHT!  We went with the domestic wagyu chef's tasting menu. They say "three courses" but what they mean is you get three rounds of food piling up at your table. There were multiple appetizers, multiple steaks, and multiple desserts. If there was something you really wanted - they were pretty accommodating in making any changes.  On top of the three course meal - we also ordered a dozen little neck clams.  Appetizers + the clams came out and they were outstanding. The clams were fresh and delicious and the appetizers were really good. I hate to say this - but I'd even say the appetizers stood out more than the steak (I know... blasphemy for a steak place). The shrimp were the highlight of the appetizer section followed really closely by the clams.  The steaks: I can't remember... but we got 4 different cuts of steak and a bunch of sides - including the really delicious mashed potatoes. Although by this point, we were literally bursting to the seams. We ended up packing 1/2 away for snack later.  Dessert - 4 different desserts - although one of them is a fruit plate but I think that still counts since it wasn't just fruit cut up... At this point we were just trying to eat whatever wouldn't keep for a few hours because our stomachs were packed.  While the three course tasting was fun - I'd probably do this place a la carte. The portions were ridiculous for 2 people and I felt like I couldn't enjoy my steak as much since I was pretty much full after all the appetizers.   Overall, worth a visit - but come with a hungry stomach!

8lW2lduA7W2cyqkKJy1hDQ.text: This review is for the Vegas Uncorked Mother's Day Brunch.    I arrived about 25 minutes early and there was already a line almost back to the casino floor.  While we were waiting they passed out Mimosa's and Bloody Mary's.  Definitely a nice way to pass the time.  When we were seated, Food Writer Alan Richman and Chef Tom Colicchio spoke about Mother's Day and the changing face of hunger in America.  It was quite special and moving to see these esteemed professionals share such an important message.  Now onto the food:  1st Course: Scones with Creme Fraiche and Market Preserves.  The Scones were so good I finished mine without putting anything on them!  Seasonal Fresh Fruit.  A nice selection of Melons, Berries and Pineapple.  Pickled Farm Egg with Roasted Beets, White Anchovy.  Never thought I'd like this, but the combination of flavors was just fantastic!  Chilled Maine Lobster and Artichoke Salad.  I KNEW I' d like this one and I Loved it!  Wild Arugula with Shaved Pecorino.Standard Salad, but the cheese took it to another level.  House Made Porchetta with Mustard Fruits. Wonderfully rich and fatty with a contrasting sweetness from the fruit.  2nd Course Belgian Waffle with Warm Fruit Compote.  My least favorite dish of the meal.  Sous Vide Eggs, Asparagus, Morels, Ramps.  Stunningly delicious.  The Morels were absolutely fantastic!  Wagyu Skirt Steak, Salsa Verde.  Tender and Flavorful.  Braised Kubuta Pork Belly.  Best Pork dish I have ever had!  It almost brought a tear to my eye.  Creamed Spinach Gratin.  Just OK.  Desserts(So full I only tried two.) Frozen Chocolate Souffle.  Rich, Creamy, Chocolatey. YUM!  Lemon Verbena Pavlova, Strawberry Sorbet. Light crispy shell, sorbet tasted just like fresh strawberries.  This was a fantastic dining experience. The restaurant is wheelchair accessible and based on the quality of the food and service, I will definitely return for dinner in the future.

GP6du_LuiGh0vtq_ssFQFQ.text: Wowzers, this was one of the best short ribs I have ever had. And for only $39 it was a steal. I love it when I don't need to use a fork on my meat, it was so tender.   I also got the heirloom tomato salad which was huge ($16). My friend got the ceasar salad and it came with anchovies which he picked out LOL. For my starch we had the the potatoes pureed ($14) and gratin ($14). I like the puree better with the chives. The gratin had a funny sour taste to them for me. I don't know if it was the fancy cheese they used or what.   Service was impeccable. Wish he had a better table though but we took what we could get without any reservations.   You can easily spend over $100 per person here so be careful! Serving sizes are HUGE, we took everything home.

OdOc7THMVhUt2EyegEwLAA.text: I only had a snack, a lobster bisque and a beer. But what I had was excellent, and the staff were very friendly too. The fresh bread rolls are to die for.

-eURUg25JXtbJKgpMHFROA.text: I have to admit that the food is really good but I can't get past the cost ratio.  2 people at $600 plus is just to much to validate the experience.  Its the perfect choice when someone else is buying!

3kHR0vlyNt2cSVVDZjfq1A.text: Food was definitely not nearly as good as it should have been for the price. Orders were mixed up, the pork belly appetizer was three tiny slices, sommelier did not know enough... and to top it off my friend has food poisoning from an undercooked steak. What kind of meat do they serve?

qW5G7-_wu5ZWOIfHmRkyzw.text: Came here a few months ago dinner time. I love steak and I usually order ribeye medium rare everywhere I go. I didn't order the famous waygu meat (maybe I should) but I had the chewy-est rib eye ever. Ordered also the scallops which was delicious and the salad was plentiful and tasty.

AnkvuGoIZ3cENAm79g3Z8A.text: Wow.   I haven't written a review in months, but this place was so good that it took me out of retirement, Jay-Z style.. okay, maybe Brett Farve style? (I'm just praying not Michael Jordan style).   In any case, the food here was exceptional. If yelp allowed me to dock them a point on service, I would -- but that's just because I think 5-stars means perfection. The service was good, but not perfect. French Laundry service is perfect.   I went with 6 other guys and I luckily convinced them all to get the Wagyu tasting menu (domestic). It was expensive, especially with the cheapest wine we could fine ($67/bottle), but 100% worth it. I think it came out to be $160/person with tax and gratuity.  Because we were such a large group the chef would allow us to sample everything -- 7 different appetizers, 7 different cuts of meat, and 7 different desserts. Of course when it came time for dessert no one had any interest in eating anymore.   Peter Luger's in NYC has long held my top-spot for steakhouses, and it'll continue to do so, but just because it's so iconic and traditional. When I want to have fun and eat a ton of variety (at a steakhouse!), I'll go back to Craftsteak.  Extra notes:  - Dressy in Vegas doesn't mean dressy. Jeans and a shirt that isn't a T-shirt is totally acceptable (and normal).  - The steak tartare here was the best I've ever had in my life.  - The place is really big, and not intimate. They do have booths, but I'd skip it for a romantic date. - They have the best ice cubes in the world here.. look for an attached photo.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Awesome perfect ice &#34;cube&#34;

09QIvXji2wy-VxjuCaPNHg.text: Hands down the BEST, most PERFECTLY cooked Filet I have ever eaten. Went with the Wagyu Domestic Chef's Selection, a perfect 4 course meal!  The desserts (Monkey Bread and Carmel Cheesecake) were the perfect finish to such a lovely date night!  Pricey, but worth every penny!

MutSYFyIli1PHXathZ04WA.text: All i can say is the the Kobe Skirt Steak ($69) is the best steak i've ever had under $100.  I've pretty much been to all the high end steak houses in LA and SD area.  I've tried other cuts, but the Skirt Steak is the best.  The grilled Ribeye is pretty good as well.    The Yukon Gold Puree is also very good.

JOhwVnwSs6XnA3wFoaRLxA.text: A great guy's night out dinner spot. Very expensive, prepare to PAY. Even compared to the other Crafts, this one stands out on price.   Take note, the fries are huge! A great thing to share with the table. The grits were tasty. The sticky bun dessert was wonderful.

8vNg9Ro3Jd_21NQYfZZHng.text: Maybe the best steak I've ever had (and I usually don't even like steak that much!). The meat's delicious, the sides are delicious, service is very attentive, the restaurant is cool-looking, and it has Tom Colicchio! And on top of all that, the prices are high, but not ridiculous. For 6 of us, with dinner, sides, dessert, cocktails, and tip it was only $550.

a6CPzZWJVWcnb-n2E_3RFA.text: I've been to Craftsteak two times. The first time was with a good friend, and I was immediately impressed by the unpretentiousness of the service and the relaxed demeanor of all its clients inside. There is something also very private about the acoustics of the restaurant--as you would be able to dine with a business client and talk shop or have a louder, more boisterous time with some friends and not feel self-conscious. On my first visit, our service was excellent and the two steaks we ordered were fantastic prepared. I really recommend any of their dry-aged beef ($45-65), as the Wagyu is a little too outrageous for a simple steak dinner ($90-$110).   My second time was with a group of three others for my twenty-sixth birthday. Even though we got the last seating of the night, our service wasn't rushed and our waiter had the utmost patience with one of our slightly demanding, pretentious friend. We all ordered steaks (I never realized how amazing a dry-aged T-Bone can be) and the accompanying sides were delicious. Do yourself a favor and get a great steak in Vegas at Craftsteak. Its an awesome way to slow down the evening and enjoy yourself outside of the hustle of that MGM casino!

GsUMzl99ywCA7jpnrEHdBg.text: After some extensive research, I decided to dine at Craftsteak to celebrate my birthday. For the most part, it was a good meal. More on that later. My party of two were seated at a larger table against the wall, which was very nice and intimate. The service here was also attentive, and the waiter wasn't afraid to let us know what he recommended and what he didn't recommend.  We ultimately ordered:  18 oz Bone-in Ribeye - Grilled to perfection, and seasoned perfectly. It's a very memorable steak if you ask me, and I'm glad that I ordered it. I know my way around a steak (especially a ribeye), and the steak they served me was extremely tender and tasty. Couldn't ask for more, to be honest.  10 oz Hangar Steak - I had heard great things about the hangar, especially how great of a value it was. This is absolutely True. If you're a fan of a charred steak, you don't have to look further. It had a lot more char than the ribeye, and while it wasn't as tender, it was nonetheless delicious.   Hen of the Woods Mushrooms - While the mushrooms did look out of this world (They're maitake mushrooms, after all), the earthy flavor was a perfect complement to the steak. I'm not a big mushroom eater, but I must say they were tasty. The texture is very interesting, but paired with a slice of the ribeye made for a divine bite of food.  Potato Puree - If you love mashed potatoes, you'll love this. What I appreciated is that it was rich, but not overly rich in its use of butter, cream and salt.   I really wanted to give Craftsteak five stars, but there was one issue that made it impossible. Prior to our entrees, they brought freshly baked bread to the table. It was warm, fluffy, crunchy and delicious. We finished it, and they asked if we would like more. The entrees took a little longer than expected to come out, so we said sure. When we received our bill, we found that they had charged us (it was marked as "AMUSE" on the bill) for both orders of bread. That's $24 for bread, which is absolutely ridiculous, especially since they DID NOT let us know beforehand. If it wasn't for this, our experience would have been perfect. Be warned!

R9aCjCLaNktxjvLD1eKSRg.text: The food was amazing. Tried the tequila and jalapeno drink. It had an interested taste but it wasn't my cup of tea. The chicken was juicy and delicious. Also had the lemon vinaigrette salad. It was a great flavorful combo. All the add on items are meant to share. Dishes are well sized and could be shared if both parties are light eaters.

kzcQcs_H4INPk-Ra7iAsGg.text: Awesome most expensive meal we've had. We went with the tasting menu for $130 each. It went above and beyond our expectations. Started us off with some delicious rolls. Brought out 2 different salads and shrimp cocktail and prosciutto which were all delicious! We finished everything in the first course. 2nd course we had a ribeye and filet cooked perfectly medium rare. We were also served the most delicious Brussel sprouts and Yukon gold potato puree (yum) and asparagus. We cleaned up everything! We were so full and satisfied and then they came out with a special monkey bread served for our 20th wedding anniversary AND 2 delicious sorbet flavors (mango and raspberry) AND a scrumptious chocolate cake with yummy strawberry ice cream. I had A. Berry for my drink which super delicious and hubby had a few Chimay beers. Service was awesome. Food was decadent. We truly enjoyed celebrating our anniversary here. You can tell Tom takes the time to make sure everyone is trained properly and the kitchen lives up to his standards. Definitely worth the splurge.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_Xlarbyjm69-EufnjVHoKw.text: This was the culinary highlight of my 2018.  The waygu tasting menu and a 5L of the 2013 Hedges Cab made for the meal of a decade for our group of fellas.  Not cheap, but worth every penny all the way down tot he famous monkey bread.  This is the special occasion dining in Vegas experience I was hoping for and received.

H29Oxa7wdJSIq6NoVOwt5g.text: Not only were all our food delicious, our service was amazing. Bernardo and Kevin were great. Bernardo informed us our food was accidentally dropped, they were very apologetic and had our food replaced in a short time. They gave us desserts on the house although they fixed the problem immediately. We will definitely come back, Oscar style filet was sooo yummy!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheesecake, loved it
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monkey bread, fantastic
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 10 oz Filet mignon, medium well, Oscar style... sooo yummy

x1RHWpCGiOch54VwJbNGhQ.text: I truly recommend this place! I had the 18 oz Ribeye steak and my wife had the 16 oz New York steak, we shared there Potato puree and man it was delicious! The service there was awesome! If ever you're in town or your a local, this is the place to be for a great dinner!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 18 oz Ribeye steak, 16 oz New York steak, potato purée and house bread
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 18 oz Ribeye steak

2c3HED23KLUxNEKHnTj-Ww.text: I love meat. I love steak. I really do. I've been to great steakhouses all over this world. I would honestly have to say this place definitely cracks my top 5. I'm still mulling if it makes top 3 but I been to some awesome steakhouses in NYC and one in Chicago. It's tough. But you know the steakhouse is damn good when you have to think about letting it crack your top 3 list of all time. Top 5 for sure.   Anyways we just landed in Vegas. We wore basically Hoodies and ripped jeans. We felt under dressed big time. But the waiters/employees never once made us feel we didn't belong. Service was phenomenal. They answered our questions. They talked to us in casual conversation. Again great customer service always makes the dining experience great and this place nailed that part down.   Now onto the food. I think you have to get the Wagyu cuts here. There are some other cuts but it seems that the Wagyu cuts is what Craftsteak is known for. I was torn between the Ribeye and the Skirt Steak. My friends highly recommended the skirt steak but I've never been a skirt steak guy unless I'm paying $20 bucks for it and there's the green Chimmichurri sauce on it. LOL. So I asked the waiter he recommended the skirt steak. It's around $82. FYI this place is not cheap, a little bit more than the traditional top steakhouses but what do you expect. It's VEGAS.  Anyways, the steak was AMAZING. Every bite felt like the steak was melting in your mouth. The flavor was perfection. Not to salty. Not to peppery. Just perfect. It didn't feel like I was eating skirt steak at all. Usually I've come to find skirt steak extra chewy but not here. It melted in your mouth. Also the dinner rolls that are complimentary were amazing. We ordered 3 side dishes. The mashed potatoes were great as well. While waiting and eating our food, we ordered an 18 year scotch. Only $20 for the glass. Not bad.   Anyways highly recommend. It's a bit pricey so if you're willing to spend some money or spend your WINNINGS this place is the spot to go at the MGM Grand Casino.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Boys and their steak.
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu skirt steak. Their signature dish. Phenomenal!
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The dinner rolls! These are amazing!

TdMu9fa6AUXaeL2t7Z9Iww.text: Poor service - long waits between courses - sides brought well after the steaks.  Overpriced - $79 for a seafood sample that was had 2 shrimp, 2 oysters some crab and lobster... definitely pass this place by - much better options in Las Vegas

FHZclvyBzbMCtO7IvWuocQ.text: We just had a very expensive meal, and the service was quite good.  We shared saute spinach, risotto, seafood platter, Kobe skirt steak, mushroom assortment.  What struck me about the entire meal is that every dish was good, but not a single dish evoked a reaction of OMG. They were all tasty, but not a single one was truly impressive.   For these elevated prices, you expect to have a reaction that is truly delicious, and it just wasn't there.  Even the complimentary bread was sorta ordinary, not nearly as interesting as top steakhouses. (for example, SW Steak at Wynn has a really impressive bread offering).  The Corkage was $50 for one bottle, which I consider to be a real scam. That is insulting.  So, in summary, a very nice ambience, good service, beautiful restaurant, expensive, and not impressive enough on the palate. I will admit that I did not have a normal American corn fed steak, and they might be better. My mistake was getting the Wagyu skirt steak - that was a very unimpressive taste.

jIP_24mh7mDALQIrsQGK2A.text: Celebrity & James Beard chef Tom Colicchio (best known as the head judge on Top Chef) opened Craftsteak (located inside the MGM Grand) in 2002 and it has been an AAA's Four Diamond restaurant since 2006.  I had a reservation through the OpenTable and overall service was excellent. The menu include the steak tasting menu (range from $125 to $275) as well as other a la carte items (first courses, main courses, and side dishes). The portion for each side dish pretty big, so it is best to share between two ~ three people.  ***  Hand-Cut Wagyu Tartare (Crostini, $24): Well seasoned beef tartare - not a bad dish to share, but personally it was a bit pricey for what it's worth.   Complimentary Dinner Rolls with Sea Salt: Soft rolls with crusty exterior - it was decent.  N.Y. Strip (Dry Aged RR, Bone In - $49): Talk about one amazing NY steak ...  yup, it was definitely one of the best steak I have ever had from any steakhouses. Incredible steak quality (tender and juicy) with flavorful au jus. I even poured au jus over the potato puree.  Potato Puree (Yukon Gold, Chives - $15): Smooth and buttery mashed potato, but it lacked strong flavors. I have had better mashed potato, but it wasn't too shabby.  Brussels Sprouts (Bacon, Bordelaise - $15): I am no brussels sprouts expert, but it was a good veggie dish.  ***  Generous portion + mouth-watering steak = one satisfying dinner. The NY steak alone was really the only reason why I decided to give 5-star instead of 4-star. I had an excellent experience at Craftsteak and hopefully one day I will get to visit another Tom Colicchio's signature restaurant - Craft (one in New York and another one in Los Angeles).

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Potato Puree (Yukon Gold, Chives - $15) &amp; Brussels Sprouts (Bacon, Bordelaise - $15)
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. N.Y. Strip (Dry Aged RR, Bone In - $49)

lxSE-WOzRQ0z9HUk1thyAQ.text: The service and food here were both top notch. The waiter gave great suggestions for sides and drinks. Additionally, service was pretty fast and attentive even though it was a full house on a packed Friday night.   The steak of course is excellent and worth every penny. It was cooked to perfection and was absolutely a high quality cut of ribeye.  It is quite expensive, I was in a party of 3 and we all had a steak/1 side order each/a few drinks and the total bill was about $500+ tip. However, I have no complaints since it was a fantastic experience.

f9JtRI1IrKjEp7-Yst9mtQ.text: ***My 200th YELP review***  Being a huge Top Chef fan I had high expectation for Mr Colicchio's restaurant and it did not disappoint! Everything from check in to service to the food was top notch, a fantastic steakhouse experience.   We arrived at 5:30 and were quickly seated in a large booth along the back wall. The restaurant its self is as expected, dark and classy with both tables and booths. Our server team of Patricia and Fabio were outstanding. Both provided us over the top service from beginning to end. We started off with a couple glasses of wine while Patricia went over the menu. Fresh, hot parker house rolls topped with sea salt arrived in a cast iron dish. This was a good start!   They have a tasting menu but we opted for a la carte. We started with splitting a caesar salad which was a great tip as its plenty big for two to share. We both ordered the 10 oz Double R filet along with the infamous potato puree, mushroom risotto and sweet butter corn.   The caesar was excellent. I asked for anchovies on the side and they were brought out in a dish of olive oil. They were also pickled which made them extra tasty! Overall the salad was good. The rest of the food came out and the filets were also served in a cast iron dish which were cooked perfectly medium rare. I immediately scooped some potato puree on my plate with much anticipation. It was so worthy of their reputation, absolutely some of the best potatoes I have ever had. I don't want to know how much butter and cream is in those but the silky smooth texture was worth every calorie.   The risotto and corn were also excellent. After savoring every bite we HAD to look at the dessert menu. It wasn't to appealing to me so I just ordered some caramel banana ice cream which was really really good. My other half had the chocolate peanut butter lava cake. It was good but not the best lava cake we have had.   Overall this was definitely a 5 star dining experience. Excellent staff and service and delicious well prepared food, can't ask for much more than that!
