Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sides- tasting menu portion. Creamed spinach, potato purée, Brussels sprouts
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu NY Strip

fzngylpzM0ODwbcG6xuT7g.text: Great service, great steaks, and a great place for a business dinner. Casual ambiance.

rocspm-U-jcFpJQo2axWOQ.text: I've eaten at a lot of good and great steak houses all over America. Sadly, this is not one of them. Food quality and service is below average.

q_88lO4-o1GCF0MOvSZSNw.text: Outstanding meal tonight.  Everything that we had was phenomenal. Well worth the price.

rCkhxJQWSksXmfLvBkqx4g.text: Try the hanger steak and the monkey bread. I went with a large group and we split several dishes. We sampled almost everything on the menu including some great wines. Great place. Great food. Great Friends. Great Experience.

xBr6DrsSgKuwx_QV8klDiA.text: One of the mainstays of Vegas. I've been going to Craftsteak for 12 years now. It's still fabulous. It's still hip, it's still busy so make a reservation and enjoy.  Went with a few friends and we all ordered a steak(I had the New York) and a few side dishes too.  We started at the bar for a martini before the meal which was made perfectly.  We moved to a great booth about 30 minutes later. I requested one. The lighting here is super cool, old school bulbs hanging From a 25 foot ceiling.  This was Friday night at 8:30 and when we were seated there wasn't a table open! You see great food, great service and consistency works every time.  I highly recommend the NY steak and whipped mashed Yukon gold potatos with the carrots as a side. (Unless the corn is in season)

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. NY steak with sides of carrots and whipped potatoes!
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Martini time at the bar before dinner!

EX8IBK47hkhn5vmUK9Zapg.text: Butternut squash soup is EXQUISITE! All the food is remarkable, a real treat for your palate. The service is outstanding, and the atmosphere is relaxed. Perfection every visit!

ROV1d16MqTjvhbJemqInDQ.text: Awesome! Awesome service, food and drinks. For an appetizer I had the fresh oysters. They had three types, so I got the special that allowed you to sample all three. YUM! For dinner, I ordered the ribeye steak. It was 18 ounces but I assumed at least 8 of that was bone. NOPE.  I think I had 17.5 ounces of steak. No way I could eat it all, but I tried.  We had several of the family style vegetables. The braised kale was the best. There were others that we had, but I cannot remember because of the kale! We were there for a corporate function and definitely blew the $65 p/day expense allowance on this dinner. It was so worth it!

8H1EkkGIFFeLPi4d3UoBGA.text: Excellent meal for 2~ not sure it was worth $300 (without even one cocktail or dessert)  but the food, service and ambience was mostly excellent.  Had the arugula & pinenut salad, glazed baby carrots, pancetta risotto, assorted mushrooms and surf and turf (filet and scallops).  The salad dressing was VERY tart and the salad was way too big or shouldve been shared (wish the waiter mentioned that). Salad could have used a few more ingredients ..maybe egg and/or bleu cheese...definitely needed something to cut the sour vinaigrette. The filet and scallops were seared perfectly and delicious. The assorted mushrooms and baby carrots with rosemary were also very good but maybe a little big for 2 people.  Great meal, bring a huge wallet.

8QoZDdmyY8pPVuwNgcxT4Q.text: Oh wow this was the most amazing dinner.  When in Vegas we always like to try new restaurants and this one is not to be missed!  Amazing on all accounts and even better than I expected or you deserve for the cost.  Absolutely phenomenal steak restaurant in Vegas and close to the KA theater if you catching the show.  I love the atmosphere and the service was phenomenal.  The lobster bisque was absolutely divine and of course the steaks were 100% worth the bill.

6eYl1M0ADe68LemdWrB0ng.text: So, as a preface, I may not remember this entire gourmet experience because I was so blown away.  If you want to read up on this magical moment, refer to the reviews of Lan N., Alan W. and Steven H. because we all shared this magical moment together.  There were so so so many amazing parts to this meal, I am hard pressed to remember them all.  I will try to give the play-by-play highlights of this Cinderella night.  I will start with the sides that I remember the most: Yukon Gold Puree.  I have no idea what else is in here besides Yukon Potatoes and Butter, but whatever it is, holy crap it is addicting.  This innocuous, off-white color side dish packs flavor and velvety smooth texture and flavor and orgasms and flavor some more all into a copper serving bowl.  This dish singularly revived my love for potatoes.  Now, on to the steaks.  I will give my shout out to our waiter for the evening on this one.  So I was part of a bachelor party of 8 gents, and we could not decide on entrees.  So as a group, we all decided to splurge on the Wagyu/Kobe taster at the server's recommendation.  OH MY GOD.   Thank you restaurant gods for blessing us with an awesome server.  The recommendation on the taster was spot on.  We got wagyu/kobe filet, ny strip, rib eye, skirt steak and flat iron.  The flavor... the texture... the color... all sooooo perfect.  My highlights for the night were definitely the skirt steak and the flat iron cut.  The flavors from those cuts were f***in amazing.  Damn, I kinda want some right now...

R-da5PJh9E7JNMUEfLDmyQ.text: Really great place! Quality is amazing. Maybe best fish I've ever had. Everything I tasted was delicious:)

suymi1qVAFVFTSDuk5CCzA.text: This restaurant makes all of its patrons who walk out feel sorry for vegetarians. I'm sorry, but it's True.  5 Stars. Times a million.  Sometimes the best approach for eating out is deferring to others' wisdom. Here, that approach really paid off. Came here for my buddy's bachelor party dinner and luckily we had a Craftsteak veteran with us (Thanks YE Steven H!). This helped the ordering process go along a lot more smoothly.  Originally we were just planning to order for ourselves, but our wily veteran felt that it would be better if we ordered the multiple cuts and shared that among us instead. Our server understood and was very accommodating, which eventually led to us getting full stacks of appetizers, desserts, and of course, THE STEAK.  I've had Kobe beef in Kobe, Japan, but this was heads and shoulders above my experience there. Every bite melts in your mouth and the juices were so good that I needed more of those delicious rolls to sop up the remaining sauce. Even our friend who usually likes his meat a little more cooked through had to give it up that these medium-rare cuts of marbled beef were sublime. That being said, even though the meat was excellent, the accompanying sides of asparagus, mushrooms, and mashed potatoes were so freaking delicious that you don't mind it taking up space otherwise reserved for the beef.  Dessert came out after we were already stuffed, but we made room for the Monkey Bread (aka the Elegant Cinnabon), Ice Cream & Sorbets, Dark Chocolate Tart, Bread Pudding, and fresh fruit. Great finish.  I honestly think if we paid twice as much, it would still be worth it.

Vr3_3SK5YofBaXZ_6_uyvg.text: Being married to a restaurant guy, a foodie myself, and of course a Top Chef fan, I was very excited to go to Craftsteak while I was in Veags this week. I had just dined at Michael Mina at the Bellagio the night before, and was on a food high. Unfortunately, that ended after my meal at Craftsteak....underwhelmed would be the best way to describe it.  The restaurant is huge, with very little intimate dining space. While I was not on a date, or with my husband, it still made it difficult to chat with the friend I was with. The service was fine, attentive, but every now and then a different server would come by and offer the same thing we had just declined from our own server. Like a car dealerhsip, I felt like they wanted to get a sale so badly that they sent in the closer. Or, they just didn't listen to each other, either way, it was awkward. It was also a little wierd having the server's stand right in the middle of the room. While I was not facing that way, I could still hear all their chatter and the clanking of plates and glassware.  The menu is appropraite for the concept, sides are family style, and there are multiple tasting menu choices based on the style of entree you chose. But beware, they start at $119 for a Angus Filet, altho it is supposed to come with multiple sides. We opted for ala carte.  I started with the Waygu Tartare. It was good, but not great. In some restaurants they mix the egg in for you, but not here, and because it was in a bowl with crostini's all the way around, mixing was difficult. They also gave me a spoon, rather than a fork. Not optimal for dealing with the dish.  Then, since I couldn't make up my mind, I ordered the Surf 'n Turf, cooked mid-rare to medium, and 2 sides; the mixed mushrooms and the white corn grits. The sides were fine, but nothing to get excited about. While they were good sizes had I been sharing, they were a bit big for one person (my freind wanted something else). As for my entree, the filet was cooked to perfection! It was just the right temperature, and my knife cut throught it like butter. On the other hand, the lobster tail was the worst thing I had ever tasted! It was so dried out, I didn't even recognize the texture, absolutely flavorless, and it wasn't served with any clarified butter, which might have helped. Not to mention that it was almost cold. I left it on the plate, and was never even asked about it. We declined dessert.  So, as you can see, our experience was okay, just not great. For the price I paid, underwhelmed is not what I was looking for. I paid the same price for the Chef's Tasting menu (with pairings) the night before at Michael Mina and that was amazing, even tho it was slightly less food, it definately left you fulfilled. I would not go back to Craftsteak, and wished that I had spent some of the cost of dinner actually gambling. At least there is a chance of winning that way.

V6tDs7UJ_OhwsLI4-404cA.text: I am not a big red meat eater by trade. In fact, I've never really had a good quality steak before. I've had steak, just not a dry aged top quality prime cut. So I figured if you're going to do something first, do it right. This place is definitely a special occasion place, unless you're the Monopoly man. It is very pricey. However, one does not feel ripped off. Meaning I have been to equally pricey places where you leave feeling hungry and kinda bamboozled. They still give you large shareable portions here, so nobody will leave feeling the need to hit up the White Castle after to fill in the nooks and crannies (although I did because I'm a fat monster). The 32oz Porterhouse was fantastic, it was interesting to compare each side of the cut - I preferred the filet, but only slightly. We had waygu tartar which was just insanely decadent and so very clean tasting. We even sprung for a $140 bottle of wine, which is outrageous by my typical wine drinking standards. But it seemed reasonable at the time considering there was bottles on there up to $12,000!! Their wine list is the most crazy thing I've seen. If you can't find a bottle to impress your date or business client's here, then you won't find it anywhere. They of course have all the scotches and manly cocktails you'd expect at a restaurant dedicated to eating cows too. So in short, Ron Swanson would approve of this place.

rQztqTgyn_0EgwL4BYeG4Q.text: I have to add to my review that the best steak I have ever eaten in my life was the Waygu Strip Steak I had just a few nights ago.  Paired with some 2006 Silver Oak Cabernet, it was the best dinner I have ever had!    End your meal with some monkey bread and their awesome french press coffee and you will feel like you're in heaven.  This place is definitely my favorite steak house in Vegas.  It never fails and is sooooooooo worth the long wait.

MxQc6rPaE8gSwR2aae7IUQ.text: Craftsteak was expensive and underwhelming. Prior to my visit, I had even been warned of this by friends. Apparently I had to learn the hard way.   Overall, dinner was not necessarily bad. But it was disappointing for a meal that costs about $100 per person. In fairness, the scallops were solid. But I have had better, larger ones at about half the price.  The sides, shared among a table of four, were a let down. From best to worst: the yukon gold puree, the mushroom melange, and the au gratin potatoes.   The yukon gold is unique and the only item I would order again if I were to return. Which is not something I am dying to do. In my opinion, CUT still remains the best steakhouse in town.

kmIdydC3W-AYgbvcNiMZCA.text: We had a wonderful experience at this lovely restaurant. The Diver's sea scallops were cooked to perfection. Maui onions will blow your mind. I highly recommend eating here.

4YALY__IWFaF1eZpVvsxAA.text: Walking into this place, I knew that I was in a high class restaurant. We were seated in our own individual booth shaped like a U and facing the rest of the restaurant.   Their steaks were delicious and cooked to perfection. My rib eye's temp was just right and the meat was extremely flavorful. I also got to try the Wagyu NY strip...$135+ for a piece of meat as big as my fist! But heck, although I felt like I was eating gold, it proved to be one of the most delicious piece of meat I'd ever tasted. It was melt-in-your-mouth, flavorful, and absolutely the most tender thing I'd ever had.   The side dishes, like the wild mushroom medley, were absolutely delicious!  The service was excellent. Some of the steaks were a little too charred and, unintentionally, this was casually mentioned to the manager who was making rounds at each table. She apologized profusely and comp'd one of each of the entire dessert menu! Wow, now that's wonderful customer service. I would not hesitate to come back here again...gosh, if only it wasn't so pricey! The desserts were so delicious and so delicately made. I'm normally not one to order desserts, but knowing how deliciously they made their desserts, I would definitely save some room next time.  Craftsteak, you are (so far) an unbeatable Vegas favorite (for a steakhouse).

DFOfmxvkahFmuWF3VugS1Q.text: The food is mediocre and definitely not worth the ridiculous price. We had the three course tasting (4 people) wagyu which included 3 salads, 3 filets, 1 Lobster, and 5 desserts. The salads were decent and the filets were tender but didn't melt in my mouth. The desserts looked impressive and tasted like any high end Vegas buffets.    Still haven't found a steak house that can beat or come near Peter Lugers.  Tom Colocil, please pack your knives and go.

hjuZi4fCIZACv7lZLvDIkA.text: Service and atmosphere is superb, waitresses were really helpful and polite. On the other hand, as you may know this is a steakhouse and ironically that's exactly the area where it fell short. We ordered the shortrib and the ribeye. Shortrib was OK a little on the salty side but the big disappointment was the ribeye. Lack of flavor and not tender add you would expect. I'm a big meat eater, so I know my standards are little high, but I know that they could and should do better. Being this my first time and given the experience I wouldn't recommend it to my friends.

9B8Dqoffgj4aMGFNk2sEjQ.text: This is simply one of the best meals I've had in my life (and I've had a lot of good meals). We ordered the Chef's Selection three course menu, which includes two cuts of steak and a plethora of appetizers and sides.  I was so full after this meal that I skipped breakfast the next day, and ate a light lunch.  All of the dishes were outstanding, but my favorites were the rib eye and filet steaks, the warmed frisee salad with pork bits and egg, ALL of the side dishes (asparagus, wild mushrooms and a mushroom-topped risotto) and the home-made sorbets.  Extra points: my favorite Scotch is The Glenroths, which is brand that is not commonly carried in many bars and usually bars will only stock one bottle. Craftsteak had bottles from 7 different years on hand, first time I've ever seen that.

GVkNBNP9Cugi9gLUwxu5JA.text: Dinner for two came to $325 including tax and a 20% tip.   We ordered off the the three-course menu. For this we got (total) two drinks, two salads, two appetizers, two steaks, three or four sides, and four desserts. Everything was truly delicious -- though the meal was two months ago and I've forgotten most of the details. I've been to great steakhouses and this is as good as if not better than the best.  Staff treated us like VIPs.

83mY50ZgVKEyIk8eJCGbyA.text: Great service and the wine recommendation was excellent.  That's the high point then everything was down hill from there.    Quality of food was mediocre.  Overcooked steak, salty spinach and asparagus just to name a couple.  Way overpriced for what we got.  $24 for a tiny serving of assorted mushroom was disappointing as well.  I've had much better food at other steakhouses around the country or even inside the strip. Freshly baked bread was the best part of the dinner food.

V8fdGcMCY_DzBrMW3cCHKw.text: Took the BF here in October. I went here in June but didn't get to actually eat dinner. I just had some oysters and a caeser salad, both of which were good. However, I was much more impressed with their fresh bread rolls, baked fresh, brushed with butter and topped with salt. I also had a bite of my friend's salmon -which was perfectly cooked with a very crispy skin!   Soo... I was REALLY excited to eat at Tom Colicchio's Craft but unfortunately, my meal was just okay. The bf ordered the filet, I had the salmon w/ lentils, and we had a side of gratin potatoes and a caprese salad.   Bread rolls: As good as I remembered the first time. They melt in your mouth.  Caprese salad: good but the ratios were just slightly off  Salmon: Perfectly cooked, but no crispy skin. The lentils were well cooked, especially since I don't ever find them done well in non-Indian restaurants. However, this salmon was nothing spectacular...Not, however much I paid for it spectacular!  Filet: I tried a bite of my bf's filet and it was medium-rare and juicy, but for some reason, I'd prefer to have gone to N9NE. I think it's hard to beat Dallas for steak -compared to Del Frisco's or Bob's or Steve Field's.  Gratin Potatoes: These were really really bad and bland. I think they were made with some leeks and fennel which could have been great but they really messed it up. Yuck.   Service: The last time I was here, we had great service. But this time, it was terrible. We waited so long we had to call for a waiter... We saw many people get served bread rolls before us and we were ignored a majority of the night. Maybe they thought a pair of "kids" shouldn't be eating there...    Would I eat here again? No, I can probably make bread rolls myself... If im in LV and craving steak I'm going to N9NE in the Palms or Strip House in Planet Hollywood.

7k4CHGftcNUW2iHs6cYM5A.text: Wow! Hubby and I made reservations for Craftsteak thanks to our fellow Yelpers. We had originally planned to go to Seablue, but the poor reviews for service made us change our mind. 6pm reservation, and we were seated immediately in an almost-empty restaurant. That sort of freaked me out--what Vegas restaurant is nearly desolate on a Wednesday evening? The good part of that was that our food was delivered very promptly...and the food. Oh my God.  Bread: Comes out in its own mini baking tray. Six perfect rolls topped with sea salt and served with delicious butter. They were deliciously addictive, and I wish we hadn't eaten so much of it. It really dampened my appetite...  Lobster Bisque: Holy caloric explosion, Batman! The bowl is placed in front of you with huge chunks of lobster in the bottom, and then the sous pot filled with the creamiest bisque is poured into the bowl. It was truly amazing. My husband had the Caesar salad with pickled anchovies, and it was perfect--crisp, cold, flavorful and very big for an appetizer. In hindsight, we should have split an app instead of ordering two.  Main course: Hubby got the surf and turf. His filet was delectable, but his shrimp were just okay. He liked them fine, but he referred to them as "nothing to write home about." My flat iron steak was perfectly cooked, and so flavorful that I closed my eyes with each bite. It was nearly a religious experience.   Sides: We ordered two sides, not knowing that one side would have easily sufficed. Husband got the fingerling potatoes, which were perfectly cooked, tender and flavorful. I ordered the sugar snap peas which had just been picked THAT MORNING. They were so delicious--al dente, crisp, sweet and served on some sort of light chili sauce that made the favors pop. Truly amazing.  Dessert: Just couldn't. I couldn't even finish my meal, so I wasn't about to go hog wild on dessert.  Service: Top notch. We had at least three separate staff working our table, including one woman whose only job was to place our silverware. I want that gig. Everyone was friendly, attentive and congenial. One of the most expensive meals of our young lives, but worth it in every way. And Joe was the bees knees. We'll definitely be back!  Tips: Order one side for every two people. Share your appetizers. Easy on the bread. And why bring kids to a steak house where the cheapest cut of meat is $40? Enjoy!

Sj8yIEm_kIpmh8YgDWKJFQ.text: Excellent large-format ribeye. As you would expect, the service is highly accommodating of time constraints. This restaurant is close to the event venus at the MGM Grand but is also worth going out of your way to visit.

yA4QwQCwpdZwEJrz6nlbVQ.text: This was our first experience here and everything was just as expected. The food was melt in your mouth delicious with very generous portions. The staff are all polite, professional, friendly and accommodating.  Definitely a great experience.

GeZ9mPfdQ9stDohwRoyexg.text: This was a repeat visit for me to Craftsteak. Our waitress was fantastic, the food was very good. I had the 10oz filet, which I ordered medium rare, and it came out very rare, unusual for such a quality restaurant. They handled it well, but it was surprising. My friends had much larger steaks, and one had the short rib, which they all enjoyed. We had a bunch of sides including Brussels sprouts, baby carrots and the Yukon gold potato puree.  We shared a nice bottle of wine, and while it was a struggle, we managed to share the Monkey Bread dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yukon Gold potato puree
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Baby Carrots
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monkey Bread

kTadeSXMLRiInyZ3LU1AOQ.text: What can I say that already hasn't been said.  The service was very good and staff was very attentive and helpful. The food was delicious.  Started off with dinner rolls that had the tops basted with butter and sprinkled with sea salt. The rolls were delicious.   I had ordered the Lobster Bisque. It was mixed at the table so you could see the many pieces of lobster in the bowl before the soup was poured in. It was also very delicious.  My main entree was the Snake River Wagyu Skirt steak prepared medium rare. It was very tender and was very happy that I ordered it. For my sides I had orders of Brussel Sprouts with bacon and onion and Potato Puree. Both were good but did not finish.  By this time I was pretty stuffed but there's always room for dessert right? So at the wait helps insistence I ordered the Cinnamon Monkey with Banana ice cream which I was glad I tried but also did not finish.  It was an excellent dining experience and was very happy that I was able to eat there.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu Skirt Steak with Potato Purée and Brussel Sprouts
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cinnamon Monkey Bread with banana ice cream
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lobster Bisque

RBxqc4znV6rYoemIFEpSFw.text: Each time we visit Las Vegas, dinner at a steakhouse is a must.  There are so many top rated choices located on the the strip.  My BF is a total steak connoisseur.  I trusted his taste and let him choose our date night spot.    He made reservations at Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak for the 915 slot.  Luckily we did so 2 days prior or they get completely booked.  As soon as we arrived, we were greeted by the lovely hostess.  Our table was ready in 5 minutes and we were seated promptly.    The staff at this restaurant is so fabulous and accommodating.  Our server was super attentive and friendly throughout the evening.  He served the wine and took our order right away.    The menu is simple with a variety of steak cuts ranging from domestic wagyu, A5 wagyu, filet mignon, rib eye, NY strip, hangar, flat iron, and short rib.  The wine list is quite extensive ranging from domestic to imported.    Our dinner choices: 14 oz grilled ribeye (medium rare).  Perfectly marbled and tender!  The steak is served in an iron skillet.  I think I may have gone to steak heaven.  Superb!  Surf and turf:: lobster tail and 6 oz filet (medium).  Grilled to perfection.  Most tender and juicy cut.  My all time fave!    Assorted mushrooms:: variety of 'shrooms sauteed.  Very delightful comp with your steak.    Dessert:: mango and coconut sorbet (made in house).  Light and refreshing.  Great option to cleanse the palate post dinner.    Complimentary rolls:: aka monkey bread brushed with oil and sea salt.  Warm and soft.  Delish!  The damage was about $300 for 2 including wine!!  The most amazing dinner on this Vegas trip!  5 *****star food, service and ambiance.  Bon appetit!!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 14oz Ribeye + Surf &amp; Turf (1/2 lobster tail n 6oz Filet). The best ever!

2Qa9thYoQKzrQMJwAAN65g.text: We went 2 years ago (sorry late on review)  We had the wagyu sampler.  We let the chef pick the dishes, big mistake.  The first course there was NO Wagyu item, very disappointed as it was the wagyu sampler.  The main dishes were okay, a Filet and NY steak.  Not much marbling, and the meat was a big tough, maybe they forget it was suppose to be waygu or it was only grade 1, in which we would have chosen a prime cut. Over all we were very disappointed for a $500 meal.  I emailed them about it, never heard back, guess they didn't care.

xoimsK4nWPVRENbzFgpFtg.text: 3.5 Overall  I've had my fair share of dining experiences and at this price, every dish should be memorable with its own character.  The ambiance is casual yet upscale. No need to dress up here just wear what you would to a nice brunch or something (it is pretty cold though so ladies, bring a wrap or shawl!)   Reservations for a Saturday night were pretty easy to get. We were seated within 5 minutes and handed one of the most extensive wine lists I've seen (it had an index!) The most affordable wine on the list was about $85/bottle and their corkage fee is $50. They partner with wineries to obtain special wines so I highly suggest trying one of their specials. They also have a sommelier on site, who we consulted for a red wine that would compliment both seafood and meat.  A server approached our table and took two of my friends' order and then just disappeared leaving us confused. Luckily another server came by and picked everything up for us with a great attitude.  I had the filet mignon since it's my favorite type of steak but seeing my friend's dishes, I wish I tried something more different!   I adore steak tartare but it's difficult to find a place that seasons it well. The wagyu one here definitely caught my eye but the seasoning lacked any depth. It was over-salted and I was sad lol.  Scallops were seared nicely in a simple sauce but wish there was a bit more flavor to it. Potato puree was nice but nothing I haven't tasted before.  My favorite part of the meal was actually the mushrooms LOL. The variety they had were fragrant and almost floral, which complimented the meat really well. It was a great addition.  They ran out of a wine we really wanted to try so my friend talked to our server quickly and she gave us a free monkey bread dessert at the end to share which was also a big highlight of the night.  Food wise, nothing was terribly wrong but at the price point, nothing also caught my eye or attention. This place is great for wine lover but for steak/seafood, Mastro's does the trick for me!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 10oz Filet Mignon
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pijlJxr-QDNyXKHunkay8A.text: This place was five stars when I came here about 10 years ago and had the very best ribeye ever. This time the same steak was really good but just fell short of five stars. For the price I expected it to be more tender and maybe thicker. The recommended wine was really good, my salad and potatoes were amazing. And I love the atmosphere.

p4oC3YH0yUZmIurCdXIlKg.text: It pains me to write this review because I am a big fan of Tom, Top Chef and frankly most MGM restaurants. I had been wanting to try this place for probably 5+ years now and maybe I hyped it up too much in my own mind, i'm not sure. There were some hits and misses, but after taking a few days to think about it, I'm kind of bummed out overall.   To qualify my review, I have been to some of the best steakhouses in the country, including Mastro's in Newport Beach, Cut, Ruths Chris, Golden Steer, Prime 112 in Miami, Flemmings, Capital Grill, Del Friscos, Prime at Bellagio, Hells Kitchen, etc etc.  First I will say that the sommelier who was on-staff that night (a Thursday) was excellent. Extremely friendly, knowledgeable and really made our entire experience more enjoyable. I wish I could remember his name, but he was fantastic. The $50 corkage fee was high, but it's Vegas and I know how it goes. The rest of the waitstaff was fine if not forgettable.  The bread they start you off with is crunchy, light, sweet and delicious. Perfect starter.   I ordered the domestic waygu filet. While it was good, it did not live up to the hype or the price. It was cooked a solid medium, except for the very very center which was basically raw. For $130 I was pretty let down. Not terrible by any means, but just OK. I'd skip it and maybe try the Jap next time, or just the regular ol filet.  My wife had the braised short rib and I just couldn't have been more disappointed with this dish. Chewy, fatty, and no seasoning, bland all around. I make better shortrib at home in my oven. The menu says braised 24 hours and I just don't believe it. The 24 shortrib at Hells Kitchen is unbelievably better than this, like stunningly so. I wish she would have sent it back, but she was hungry and we had a table full of people.   Other tables entrees included the surf and turf, which I didn't try, but was told it was very good and another friend had the bone-in ribeye which he said was "good, not amazing"  Sides: Carrots: bland, no seasoning, cold. Skip Maui Onion: pretty darn good, not sure if worth the price, but seasoned very well.  Potato puree: Absolutely fantastic, maybe one of the best I've ever had. Must get. Mushrooms: Shitakes, again very bland, someone missed the seasoning again.   Desert: Creme Brulee was painfully average. Not bad, just not exciting at all.   Overall: At this price point, in this town, with so many fantastic restaurants around, this is going to be a one and done for me.   Unlike a lot of people that i'm sure dine here on the corporate card, I paid for this out of my own pocket with my hard earned paycheck and left a little sad about the whole thing.

Ce1o9XfFnBflImRXcHgDeQ.text: Great restaurant from the decor to the dessert.  The fresh rolls are warm and delicious - not to heavy or "doughy" - you know the type that don't allow you to enjoy the rest of your meal. I had the hanger steak - it was cut nicely for me, in warm cookware. Even though the cut appeared to be rare it was actually tender and delicious not under cooked at all but not overcooked either - just right.  The Caesar salad - that was just OK, unfortunately they had no anchovies and the rest was very basic... so can't really speak to its full potential or lack of.  The mashed potatoes like the Caesar need some work. Good wine selection. I like the eat at the bar option. Cool place I def try again and hope it had some adjustments.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iAyMu_gVUD9KGJGikYOp5A.text: Great for business dinner or social. Our server did a very good job, she was attentive & informed. I highly recommend the wagu sampler, although wagu is pricy, this one comes with sides and dessert. The wine selection was good (they did have the Vegas surcharge). My only criticism would be that there seems to be mushrooms in everything... if that's your only negative, you are in good shape (first world problem).

DA_qw3E3e41HpbgPLLabSQ.text: I'm embarrassed to say that my affinity for Tom Colicchio has nothing to do with his position as head judge on Top Chef, rather Ronny Karem's hilarious parodying of him on Watch What Crappens podcast (Hi Ronny!) Notwithstanding my roundabout way of indulging this pop-culture -zeitgeist-meets-culinary curiosity, Craftsteak is solid.  Housed in MGM Grand, the aesthetic of the restaurant's interior is far-removed from the adjacent casino halls populated by hotel guests wandering around with their player's cards and margarita yards. The dining room is dimly-lit by gorgeous wide chandeliers, and the dark walls are adorned with jagged-lined, rough-textured art pieces. The service is (surprisingly) lightning-quick, but to no detriment of the dishes' quality. My bacon-wrapped scallops were tender and succulent and my husband's steak was a generous cut seared to perfection.   Craftsteak's only feature with which I find fault is the pricey a la carte menu; I enjoy chefs taking creative license with specials. Dinner here will set you back a pretty penny, and I am still mentally wrestling with whether our meal was worth the price.

xU5Z1jSZxr5y9zUDLsNo9Q.text: VERY disappointed!  I reserved a table with so much anticipation... it was very much a let down.  The service was FANTASTIC!   The ambience was good.  The food was just average.  I ordered the lobster bisque to start with.  It was bland.  For my entree, I ordered the Diver Scallops and Hen of the Woods Mushrooms.  The scallops were fine.  Just fine... nothing special.  The mushrooms were as dry as dust and tasteless.  After this, I didn't bother with dessert.  At these prices, I expected so much more.  Tom Colicchio would surely be upset that his name is attached to this food.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bland lobster bisque
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nice atmosphere
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Diver Scallops and (very dry, tasteless)mushrooms

IkCslRlnhizVj-obxo7yJQ.text: Underwhelming is right. Headed to the Strip as a local for a date night...and another reminder that you definitely DO NOT need to be on or anywhere near the strip for a great meal. Food was "good"..Service was "good"...but your usual hustle you in and out to get the next guest in. The most disappointing part (as it often is) is there is not much overly impressive with the food in comparison to the extremely HIGH prices. Was it s bad experience...no. Would we go back...not at all. Not intimate nor special and VERY expensive. Disappointing.

PhbmYG6sgtEin-PfRreazQ.text: Had such a great experience here! All entrees were well loved and had an amazing selection of wine. Highly recommend the salmon or the filet medium. Great ambiance and the staff was all very friendly and knowledgeable. Is even a nice place to just come sit in the bar and enjoy drinks!

xb4kovTrVtvU9Rp5-a1rRA.text: I am a big Top Chef fan and as such I was totally geeked about eating at one of Tom Colicchio's restaurants. Yelp won't let me assign half stars, but I would give it a 3.5 instead of a 3. A 4 would not be fair based on my visit. First, the service was very good. Though I did feel like they were pressuring us to proceed to the next course (It was not crowded as it was a weekday evening) they were overall very nice and accommodating. I will highlight good and bad points of the meal.  Cocktails: Delicious and refreshing.  Appetizer: We got the prosciutto and balsamic peach appetizer. Really good prosciutto. Loved it. We also got rolls and they were great. Hot and fresh from the oven.  Entrees and sides: This is where it went downhill a bit. We ordered the short rib, which was delicious and tender. So good! No complaints. We also ordered the domestic wagyu skirt steak, which was highly recommended by our server. I ordered it medium rare and it was in fact cooked perfectly. HOWEVER, it came out to me room at temperature--at best. No warmth. No sizzle. Cold skillet. That's not how a steak should be served. Ever. Huge ding right there. Let's move on to sides. We got the grits, which came out hot and were very yummy. Thumbs up. Then we got the honey glazed carrots, which aside from not being that unique in flavor, were also at room temperature. They should have been at least warm.   Dessert and coffee: We ordered the mango passion fruit sorbet and it was GREAT! We also ordered the monkey bread with banana ice cream, and while it was full of wonderful flavors and made to order, it was also a bit burnt on the bottom. Not caramelized. Burnt. We ordered cappuccino and it was really good.  I think all of these dishes could have been awesome (except for the carrots, perhaps). But the execution was not on point this visit. The serving temperature being so far off was a big deal.

1zBNuBH9nx48F4U9y8s79Q.text: Lobster bisque is good. Steak was swimming in grease.  They serve steak on hot metal dish but greasy.

kxXJTlMT_x94Evv0OJ6fQw.text: Went with a group of 9 and we were all blown away at the entire experience. Between the staff, their recommendations, the drinks, the apps, the dinner and finally the desert; it all felt like an amazing experience.   Our waiter suggested an excellent choice of their box option which gave us an overwhelming amount of food with a fantastic variety. Awesome value for what were able to sample. 2 each of 4 different steaks (yes 8 steaks), 3 apps and 4 deserts. It was simply incredible. An investment for sure but worth every penny.

kq2BX4ad3c-RfD6IQ2x60Q.text: Had the 18oz Ribeye, the service, the food, the drinks was off the chain! The bread and the team taking care of you was top notch!  I will definitely be back!

NLGvJD1BdJNvjcJn16DZBg.text: My boyfriend and I recently dined here and the food and service was amazing. Whenever we go to steakhouses he always orders the filet and I always have a bite. But the bone in filet here was so tender and juicy, it's probably one of the best I've tasted! I love mushrooms and always order them as a side instead of a starch. I'm not sure the names of all the different mushrooms in the assortment but i enjoyed them all. My boyfriend loves the fingerling potatoes here, they're very seasoned and a little on the salty side for me. But what i found interesting is they're a red/ purple color potato. I also ordered the scallops. A few years ago when I wasn't eating red meat, I ate here and I had ordered the scallops and they were so delicious. They were just as i remembered them! For dessert we had the cinnamon monkey bread which I enjoyed but I think next time I'll ask them to not top it with so many chopped pecans. I'm not a huge fan on nuts on my desserts. But the warm monkey bread and ice cream were the perfect amount of sweetness to end the meal.  Our servers were very attentive and knowledgeable of the menu. They even offered to bring us another plate of bread since we finished it before our food was served. I had some leftovers and they packed it to go for me very neatly with utensils.

DrBXU6q4g047g5ON4quS1A.text: Now this is eating.  American kobe steak.  The hands down greatest steak I have ever eaten.  American kobe (wagyu) beef is a cross between the full Japanese cow and Angus.  This was done because the wagyu beef is extremely marbled, almost white and thus not as appealing to Americans.  Plus American kobe is alot less expensive since you only need one kobe cow to tango.  That being said Craftsteak does actually have 100% wagyu but it is crazy expensive.  They also have non kobe steaks, which are damn good.  Have tried the new york and it was awesome.  But I am here for the kobe steak.  So back to the meal, Craftsteak is located in the MGM Grand hotel.  I've been here twice now.  You can either order a la carte.  Steak, appetizers, sides, deserts etc, similar to other places like Ruths Chris and Flemings.  Or you can get a one of their taster meals, the basic one being $130 a person.  Pretty damn expensive but wow, that is eating like a king.  I've tried it both ways and its great either way.  Appetizers include kobe tartar which is awesome.  Sides like baby broccoli, sauteed mushrooms, and the spinach are good.  The potatoes are not as good as other steak places I've been to.  The deserts are pretty solid as well, ice creams, monkey bread, etc.  Most importantly though are the steaks.  The Flat iron is noticeably different from other steaks, but the kobe skirt steak, their signature steak, and kobe ribeye are awesome.  The ribeye is richer, almost too rich, than the skirt and is probably better but the skirt is definitely more manageable.  Both are great but if you are ordering a la carte and have to eat the whole steak yourself, get the skirt.  A la carte, the skirt is also 35 dollars cheaper as well.      The various samplers are expensive and worth it if you are very hungry.  But most people will not finish their meals and to leave any kobe steak over would certainly be a sin.  Also remember that kobe steaks are more filling than regular steaks, so choose wisely.  I find that I am fine ordering the kobe skirt and 1 side.  This place is excellent.

u8PAbuTHX6KvNNBR4BCTcg.text: The wagyu was very well prepared, and the appetizers were fantastic (the brussel sprouts and steak tartar especially). The desserts were underwhelming, as was the service - although the service may have been an issue because I went during a very busy time.  I'd suggest doing the chef's choice for wagyu. Or just get the skirt steak, which is stellar. It's a good restaurant, but it doesn't compare to great restaurants in other major cities - the ambiance isn't as nice, and the wait staff seems overburdened.

fY3Yp0qQlopIfsz_quZljw.text: The wagyu skirt steak was pretty awesome.  I am not a big fan of wagyu cuz its like eating a fat piece of fois gras.  I should like fat on fat cuz i am fat but its just too fatty for me.  WTF happened to the Fatty A.  Lame.  The skirt steak was perfect cuz the meat is tougher but with the extra fat it was perfect.  I compared it to the bone in rib eye and both had different flavors and texture.  The only bad part of the meal was ordering wine at this joint.  The winelist is massive and it took them over 30 minutes to get someone to take my wine order.  Lamers.  We tried a bottle of the Vineyard 29 but I wasn't impressed.  -1 suckaz.

c-w0Z86BSkpMehT2cFp3-g.text: Went there last week, dinner for two. It was expensive! Restaurant was packed, we had reservations for 9:30pm. Those without reservations had to eat at the bar. Lighting was dim, but I didn't mind. We were seated in a booth in the back, but once again I didn't mind because the place was completely full for the night. It was CES week after all... We didn't have breakfast or lunch that day. We snacked on a berry danish and smoothie from Jean Philippe in the afternoon so we could eat like pigs at night. ;) We ordered a few martini's and they were quite good. At $13 each, it's quite reasonable/cheap because 1) it's Vegas, 2) well made, 3) quite strong, 4) compared to drinks @ Sushi Samba, these were spectacular! We settled on the wagyu's chef tasting menu $130pp. I read a ton of reviews before I came here and heard how good the rolls were. They're just rolls, how good could they possibly be?? OMG! The dinner rolls were light and airy, came out warm and had just a touch of salt. I could've eaten a ton, but I didn't. We should've taken some to go, and made wagyu sandwiches with them.. =D 4 Apps:  Watercress and Cucumber Salad: really quite refreshing, yet very simple. Buffalo mozzarella: really liked this. I don't like cheese in general but the mozzarella was so creamy and with a touch of balsamic vinegar, it was delish! Hawaiian Prawns - seriously these were probably the best prawns I've ever had. Tons of flavor, thank goodness for the dim lighting because we sucked on the heads like Anthony Bourdain says it really is the best part.  Prosciutto with Pear Chutney: nothing special.  Main:  Wagyu skirt steak: my friend loves ribeye because of the fat content but he said the skirt steak was actually better then the ribeye... It was quite flavorful and charred just a bit on the edges. Wagyu ribeye: it was good, even better the next day.   Sides: Wild mushroom medley: delicious though a little bit too salty for me Creamed Yukon Gold Potatoes: creamiest mashed potatoes with so much butter.. I would never put this much cream/butter in my own potatoes, but they were so....good. Asparagus: grilled, something you can make at home, but good  I probably only had a slice each of the ribeye and the skirt steak because I was mainly concentrating on the sides. I don't really like steak, so my friend was eating most of the meat. Thank goodness we didn't have lunch that day because we were so full. We took what was left of the steak to go and we still had dessert coming up.   For dessert we were brought out: Dark Chocolate  Molten Cake, an assortment of Sorbet, Cherry Cobbler and some Grilled Pineapple. We didn't really care for any of them. So 1 star off for that. I've had way better molten cake, but I live in nyc; we have good food whether it's cheap or expensive. The grilled pineapple - really? who would pay for that? Sorbet was okay but I had better just the other night at the Venetian. Maybe a lil too icy and not enough fruit. I don't really think cherry cobbler belongs in an upscale restaurant. I want something richer or fancier, not something I could get at a diner. We took the desserts back to hotel as well. We spent a little over $400 since we had 6 drinks between the 2 of us. The next time I'm back in Vegas, I'd go back for drinks, but I'll probably check out CUT or Delmonico.

jWY8D3khpd_Z3eDXrWZLRw.text: I've kept my eye on Craftsteak as well as a couple other restaurants but I was feeling for a good flat iron two nights ago and choose this place over Fleur De Lys and Mesa Grill.   Holy hell. I was so pissed to find out that Restaurant week in Vegas ended during the first couple days of my visit. I wanted the get the tasting menu that was $85pp but only $50 the day before! Should have punched myself in the face for that mistake.  Either way, everything was freaking delicious. The strength of the meal came in the steaks, scallops and sides. Perfectly cooked to a medium rare. The appetizers were good, but comprised of nothing cooked, so it was harder appreciate dishes that came in various marinades and dressings (we had shaved fennel salad, cucumber and watercress salad, buffalo mozzarella and proscuitto with figs). I would've appreciated the roast quail but they were out for the night. Dessert was good too, I'm a sorbet girl so I loved the peach and chocolate sorbet. Tasted like cocoa ice cream without the ice cream texture that I don't like. We also had molten chocolate cake and monkey bread which my bf loved.  Portions were HUGE. We could've fed at least 3 ppl with the food we received.  Service was great. The waiters weren't snobby at all, even though me and my bf were the youngest kids there. I was a little annoyed that they kept on referring to the Wagyu beef as Kobe...because its not the same thing. But the "lead" waiter even recommended a cheaper tasting menu that fit our tastes better, instead of recommending the more expensive one that would result in a bigger bill.  Why the one star off? I'd like to see a better appetizer in the tasting menu we got. Also, I really thought the food was good but our bill came out to $275 for two people (we split 3 glasses of champagne) which I thought was hefty for food that was plain in idea and execution and not super innovative or unique. I think if I paid Restaurant Week prices I'd be a little happier but all in all, we had a great meal.

S54VxPeHJU9EF__mkImBXA.text: The poor lighting was just another way of Tom Colicchio telling me that he knows more about fine dining than I do. The dim lighting offered a very rustic and warming ambiance. Dark woods and Edison-ion incandescent light bulbs created a mood that was more of a brew master's basement rather than Vegas Strip fine dining. The service of course was an obvious reminder that you pay top dollar for the best. The duet of servers we had were in tune with the menu as well as my near endless need for ice water while eating.  Though I have always enjoyed steak, I honestly acknowledge that to me good meat tastes like good meat and that great meat tastes like more expensive good meat. I'm happy to note that for once in my life I was proven wrong. The American-Kobe was literally perfect. The braised sauce was itself worth its weight in flavor and the meat was cooked to perfection. Of course the dim lighting may have hidden any imperfections in presentation, but I'm giving Tom the benefit of the doubt. I shared with my date the Flat Iron American Kobe and the Duck Confit.   Having never heard of Monkey Bread, seeing it on the dessert menu was a bit surprising. Never mind the fact that my date loves both monkeys and bread; I was quite curious myself to see what this was. Turns out, it's quite the dessert. Dusted with cinnamon and served piping hot, the bread looked much like a regular muffin. However once the eating takes place all muffin comparisons stop. It comes apart in chunks, which can be dipped in a caramel frosting which it is paired with. Its warm buttery taste alone is delicious, but as with most things in life; frosting takes it to another level.  Stuffed full and impressed enough to want to write about it, I happily paid my bill (which given its price, I would have not deemed worth it if it had not been one of the best places I've ever eaten at).

5ApR5eAWK_SiF7ouMDCe8w.text: OH. MY. GOD. The best meal I've ever had in my entire life! My boyfriend surprised me with reservations at Craftsteak the last time we went to Vegas. I am a huge fan of "Top Chef" so it was a great surprise!  We sat at the bar having some drinks while we waited for our table. The martinis are wonderful and STRONG. Wow! The bartender was like an encyclopedia on whiskey and shared his wealth of knowledge with anyone sitting at the bar.   The menu is done ala carte, so be prepared for that. The bread they bring is probably the most amazing thing I've ever eaten in my life! Soft, gooey, salty, delicious!!!! The steak was PERFECT in every way. I had the asparagus as my side (delicious and perfectly seasoned). My boyfriend had the fingerling potatoes. Those weren't anything special, in my opinion.  The steak, by the way, was I believe 12 ounces. So you will definitely be FULL. We did not have room for dessert--which was very sad. :( The woman next to us got the surf and turf dish (the lobster looked amazing) and she also had the chocolate souffle. My only regret was that we didn't get dessert!  The restaurant was elegant and romantic and the service was impeccable. My favorite fancy restaurant in Vegas!

TnQKpaSd6-Xyiv1Uc02N2Q.text: In three words. Not Worth It. The place is way over priced for the cold food that you are served. My wife had the filet which was not hot and lacked flavor. I had the waygu skirt. It had flavor but came out cold as well. Diver scallops, taste good, also cold. Best part of the way over priced dinner was the oysters which are pretty hard to screw up. Service was Ok. I will not be recommending this place or will I be back. My advice is get out the hotel and of the strip to find better restaurants.

Es-6i6AfEpp2dsHe4XehYQ.text: Sugar Bear and I dined at Craftsteak before rushing to the Cirque du Soleil show, KA. We had to request the earliest possible reservation so we could fit in a multicourse meal. MUCH to our delight, they have a special 'pre-show' meal that is MUCH cheaper than regular meals. It was 3 courses, and we chose to add wine pairings.   We began with cocktails prior to our appetizers. Then a lovely wine with a large variety of appetizers arrived. I was already feeling full, and tipsy, when our entree and next wine arrived. We could not finish everything and it was time to get to the show. It was an emergency! Food courses were left and we had to leave! What were these two foodies to do?   Our 'craftily' accommodating waiter came to the rescue! He bagged up our left overs and kept them in the kitchen while we went to the show. He invited us to return after the show to enjoy our desserts and final wines at the bar upon our return. How is THAT for great service?   When we returned, our waiter was swamped with other customers. He did not work the bar area. But, he came over to serve our desserts AND checked on us to make sure we were still happy before we finished. We had already paid our bill and tipped him before the show, so he could have totally been done with us. He really went above and beyond in the realm of customer service.   Great food, great service, BEAUTIFUL restaurant. You REALLY need to go here if you are in Vegas.

hPTKKcAVIFnVTaj2cytCpg.text: Best steakhouse I've ever been to. Food was top-notch, service was fantastic, AND they gave us complimentary corkage. I still dream about how good the steak was at this place! Highly recommend!

Tf4pdDNxqYebsjZW3QrbvQ.text: Came here for NYE and had a great time with my friends. Only complaint is that  took 1/2hr to get table ready after we arrived for our reservation time. Besides that food and service was great. Menu may be confusing, but waiter will be happy to explain anything, just ask.

_l9GIZIp20bxX_Xy9-EWNA.text: Hmm...I honestly think that Crafsteak is a bit overhyped on Yelp.   My boyfriend and I ordered the tasting menu this past weekend, and it was just allllllright. Potato puree (basically mashed potatoes), quail, and chocolate souffle dessert were the standouts and all very very good (the souffle AMAZINGLY so.) But for entrees, both types of steaks were just okay..scallops were pretty lousy. I've made better myself, and they were on the smallish side. You'd expect big juicy plump ones considering you only get TWO! Ironically, they serve you HUGE PORTIONS of everything else. It really is way too much food.   They focus on quantity over quality, for reals.  Other than the food, the service was great, and the ambiance is kinda cool...not what I was expecting though. If you're looking for a romantic/fancy steakhouse type of place for a date or special occasion...try somewhere else. I'd recommend Craftsteak for groups as their portions are HUGE and it's pretty casual and not pretentious at all.

xoa982FlEgbw4BeJq1ZkYA.text: Tried the Wagyu Beef Chef's Menu, paired with wines.  Very tasty and more than abundant food.  My one regret is that we didn't get to try the desserts at our leisure.  We ran into a time crunch to attend our show and had to pack out our sweet treats for late that night.  Overall a good steak house with high quality food.

1yiqEMVTHWu0czM1HyzxdQ.text: Hmm, restaurant from award-winning Chef, my expectations are high.    What a mistake to order the Charcuterie Sampler, please skip. I would suggest ordering the lobster bisque for appetizer instead, taste much much better. My friend and I shared Beef New York Strip and it didn't disappoint.  It is a bit expensive but we shared a dish so we shared the cost =D and the portion was big enough for 2 people.  Ambiance is nice, low light settings with candlelights, can be very romantic for a first date.

LdhYxFyj0FOFbANUVQK2Ww.text: This is the best restaurant at which I have ever eaten. I went with my boyfriend for my birthday dinner and we were treated like royalty. I ordered the Kobe fillet mignon. It was $110 but I've never eaten a piece of meat like it. Just phenomenal. He got chicken, which was by far the best chicken I'd ever eaten, as well. We shared yukon gold potato puree and green beans. The beans were a bit salty, but that's the only compliant I have about the entire night.   The service was impeccable. We're only 21 and they didn't make us feel inferior or anything. It was obvious that we're young but it didn't matter. I'd never been served so well in my life.  The actual restaurant is beautiful. Dark, romantic ambience. We didn't have dessert or drinks. We looked at the dessert menu and it looked delicious but we were so full that there was no way we could fit it in!  My boyfriend paid so I don't know the exact total, but for two people, expect to pay well over $200, obviously depending on what you get. But please please please, if you have the money, DO experience Tom Coloccio's masterpiece of a restaurant. It was incredible!

RCrZQhdrVdWOvhsYUA8XFA.text: We were at MGM  to see KA and didn't have time for a full dinner before the show.  We stopped in and sat at the bar (Halfsteak) for a drink and appetizer before the show.  Our bartender was quick and courteous.  We were deciding between 2 things on the bar/appetizer menu and asked the bartender for a suggestion.  He said "hands down, go with the Braised Beef Short Ribs, it's just ridiculous how good they are".   The plate came with 2 short ribs (average size which isn't very big) and the sides on a separate plate.  The bartender puts the food in front of us and waits for us to take a bite...IT WAS AMAZING!...  I looked at the bartender smiled and said "that is ridiculously good!"  I would have to say this is some of the best flavor I have ever had. It came with 2 sides, we got Yukon Gold Potato Puree and Fries, both were ok (it also came with a basket of bread).    The ribs and 2 sides were $17, you don't get a lot but for me it was worth it for the taste.  The regular dinner menu is very expensive.  Maybe will come try it if I ever have a good night at the tables.  But we will definitely be coming here every trip for an appetizer.

iTg4U1oa8IE0rfFBTWUxAA.text: Four of us just had dinner at Craftsteak last night and it was absolutely fantastic! It literally was one of those amazingly satisfying and wonderful meals that you will never forget! We had the Beef Tasting menu and decided to all get different types to share: Filet, Ribeye, Short Ribs and Rack of Lamb.  All were just FABULOUS! Cooked to perfect Med Rare, presented beautifully and simply and seasoned to perfection.  The whipped potatoes were the best potatoes I have ever had in my life, and the mushrooms were divine. I can not say enough about this place.  Our server Jeff, was just superb and took wonderful care of us.  He really made us feel special!  I will recommend this spot to everyone I know and will remember this great meal for years! Please don't miss the opportunity to go here if you are in Vegas you will not be disappointed!

6D3U_xPqb9ZQh5CT7AL1pQ.text: We had a great meal.  We did the Domestic Wagyu for the table.  Got, filet, NY Strip, Ribeye, and Skirt.  While it was very interesting for everyone to be able to compare the different cuts, we all agreed that the Skirt Steak was the best.  This ain't yo momma's skirt steak. Trust me.  For the amount of money we dropped on a party of 4, it was extremely pricey.  But the meal was great.  The service on the other hand was disappointing.  No different than Maggiano's or PF Chang's.  For a $1600 check, that just doesn't cut it.  We also got stuck at a table in the bar, which I did not enjoy.  Definately ask for a table in the dining room.  Finally, the Warm Frisee salad was spectacular!  I am still giving this 4-stars because the food was that good, and my guests thoroughly enjoyed it.

VCZp4jN1FvO_c76hH1otbA.text: You want to be hypercritical of the place, given the scathing remarks Colicchio throws at the Top Chef contestants.  But then you realize he's the head judge for a reason.  Craftsteak was a precision performance, reminiscent of the Blue Angels, executed expertly from beginning to end.  The hostess was able to accommodate our last second switch from party of two to party of four.  No problem.  No delay.  It was as if they were expecting it.  The table had already been set for four.  Our waiter and his assistant (Eric and Franciscio--how often do you remember the names?) were top notch, ensuring us a well timed courses.  Our water glasses never approached empty.  Details.  Our group decided on the special prix-fixe/tasting menu they happened to be offering.  For $75 per person ($105 with three wine pairings), we were treated to family style service of a variety of fantastic dishes.  The starter was a lobster bisque, which was superb.  I'm not exactly sure what the seasoning was, but it might have been saffron, and just enough of a hint at that.  There were just enough pieces of lobster so that it was not too heavy as a starter.  Delicious.  The next course included Caesar salad, roasted peppers, and prosciutto.  Yum, yum, and yum.  We knew by then that we were in for something special.  Main dishes:  Sliced Kobe sirloins, a marinated skirt steak, seared scallops, with sides of sweet potato puree, fried artichokes, and creamed spinach.  This is where we turned into savages, ate with our hands, and communicated in snorts and groans.  Everything was cooked perfectly, seasoned perfectly, portioned perfectly.  I cannot tell you what the four dessert samplings were.  I remember them being brought to the table.  I remember they looked nice.  I remember spoons.  Chocolates, creams, fruits.  It's all a dream to me now.  Colicchio mentioned the importance of a good dessert on last night's episode (restaurant wars) and I now know that he is a man of his word.  You might balk at spending $210 for two people for a "tasting" menu, but you definitely get your money's worth with this menu.  There was more than enough food to go around.  This will go down as one of the great dining experiences of my life.  As I lay in bed later that night, the best kind of indigestion interrupting my sleep, I thought about how difficult it must be to achieve this level of perfection.  And I thought, you poor, poor Top Chef contestants--good luck to you!

o_ZTjioTmfWsfNDIVnEWkQ.text: Another trip to Vegas and another great meal.  We went here with 9 guys for a bachelor party and it was damn tasty. We ordered the Wagyu beef dinner for the table where you all pay a flat fee and they bring every imaginable cut of Wagyu beef (strip, filet, skirt steak, etc) along with appetizers, side dishes, and desserts. In fact, they brought ALL of the sides.   My favorite sides were the Mushroom risotto and the sweet corn, damn those were good. The meat though was so damn succulent and tasty you won't get a better batch of steaks anywhere.   By the time dessert came around we were really full, but they brought us 2 of everything. My favorite was the vanilla bean cheesecake and the bear claw things.   All in all +5 for the taste of the food. Amazing.  -1 for the price. You go in knowing it is going to be expensive... but, they charge you a 50 dollar "large group fee", make you pay a $500 deposit, and a mandatory 20% tip.  Not including drinks, it was about 200 bucks for dinner.

2P9D-6d0uum-T4Un7x529w.text: Yes. This is how a Vegas restaurant should be.  Service was impeccable from start to finish.  All the staff seem to be enjoying themselves and friendly with each other.   Both my servers were very informed on the menu items and had good insights on the dishes I asked about.   I had the warm frisee salad which was great, and had chunks of bacon and a soft egg white on top. They were able to portion down the starters and sides since it was just me.  The potato puree is rich potatoey goodness with chives.   The star of the show was the Wagyu ribeye. Maybe the best steak I have ever had   Every bite was the perfect bite of meaty, grilled goodness.  You pay a huge premium, but there is a difference.  They don't offer grass fed beef, because according to him the majority of their diners don't even care or know the difference.   I enjoyed the roasted shallot that came with the steak and The roasted maui onions are sweet and a great complement to your steak.

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Wagyu  ribeye. Drool.
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Warm frisée salad.

YY1EGmZcYMzrL7HGaoPS0A.text: Great experience.  Dined at the bar and Larry the head bartender enhanced the experience with very good recommendations.  Two smoking barrels, their batch barrel aged Manhattan was a great start.  For dinner, had the filet and roasted artisan cauliflower and both were wonderful.  I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Tom Colicchio's Craftsteak - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OVl--oZxgvlJdDqDVzXXjg.text: The wagyu is worth dying for! The customer service is spectacular as well. It is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for. Quality over quantity!

KEctGCCo0jlDYzziAMtDHQ.text: I went here with the highest expectations and Craftsteak exceeded them. You can get Angus beef, prime, dry aged, etc....etc at any steakhouse. You can't get Wagyu. And if you're going to get Wagyu, go to Craftsteak and get the Chef's Wagyu Beef Selection. This is the best value for Wagyu beef and you won't regret it. You are permitted to request and substitute as you wish. Just make sure you go in with an appetite. Service was impeccable and easily five stars from Eric and his team.  I went with two other hungry buddies and had three amazing courses, all five stars. We arrived 15 minutes before our reservation on a Friday night and we were seated immediately.   Drinks: complimentary champagne (thank you), 18 year Jameson, and $45 wine flight with chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon, and tokaji.   Appetizers: dinner rolls, frisee salad, shrimp cocktail, heirloom tomatoes, and buffalo mozzarella.   Entrees: Wagyu filet, Wagyu skirt steak, and Wagyu strip with potato puree, roasted peppers, and Brentwood sweet corn as sides.   Desserts: Monkey bread, carrot cake, blueberry creme brulee, fruit plate, sorbet assortment, and after dinner chocolate brownie/cake.  With all that food, the beef was still the star. I would do it again in a second and would recommend this restaurant to anyone that loves beef.

_FUwVBAxZCqMG5FQ9hitAg.text: Ever since I started watching Top Chef on Bravo, I've been dying to try one of Tom Colicchio's restaurants, and even though I live in LA, I haven't had a chance to try the one closer to home.  So, I was super excited to try Craftsteak with my friend.  The service was impeccable.  Our server gave us his recommendations on the menu and since it was our first time at the restaurant, he suggested we try the Chef's Beef Selection Tasting Menu.  It was such a great value, and it allowed us to try smaller portions of several of their dishes.    We opted to try their Avocado salad (delicious!!!), Italian Buffalo Mozzarella salad (would be fantastic as a caprese salad!), Lobster Bisque Soup (it was only mediocre in my opinion), 1/2 dozen raw oysters- we had the kumamoto and miyage oysters which were fresh and delicious).  For the sides, we ordered the mushroom assortment, fingerling potatoes, and potato puree.  Everything tasted amazing.  The sea salt buns with butter they give you complimentary are to die for.    For our main entree, I ordered the grilled Ribeye medium rare, and my friend ordered the roasted New York Strip medium.  Here is where everything went downhill unfortunately.  The steak was TERRIBLE.  I have eaten at a lot of steakhouses, and eaten a lot of steaks in my lifetime.  This is by far one of the WORST steaks I've had at a fine dining restaurant.  First of all, instead of bringing out a roasted New York Strip, a grilled New York Strip steak came out.  My friend opted not to return the dish because she didn't want to waste food.  The steak came out on a hot dish, sliced off the bone and covered in I believe a bourguignonne sauce.  It looked beautiful, but the steaks were SO TOUGH and tasted so bland.  When I looked at a slice of the steak, it had no marbling and no fat whatsoever.  The sauce didn't taste particularly good, and the server never mentioned that the steak even came with a sauce drizzled on top of it.    We ended the meal with an assortment of desserts which were also delicious.  It included monkey bread with a side of sour cream and brown sugar ice cream (it was too sour for me-- tasted weird), a chocolate tart, coconut ice cream (so good!), passion fruit sorbet, and a fruit plate.  It was so unfortunate that everything BUT the steak was delicious, considering it's a steakhouse.  Would not recommend for steak and I want to love this restaurant so much, but how can you go to a steakhouse to eat everything EXCEPT for the steak?    Service- 5 stars Salad/Appetizers/Sides- 5 stars Dessert- 4 stars Ambiance- 5 stars Steak- 1 star :(

OCfyEKKSz87GPQf1hfzkhA.text: I had high hopes for Craftsteak and was looking forward to it for the boyfriend's birthday dinner. We ordered the 18 oz ribeye (very tender and perfectly cooked), hangar steak (great char and dipping sauce), potato puree and mushrooms (both were mediocre) between the two of us.   I would have given the restaurant four stars if they hadn't charged us $24 for the house bread. It was brought directly to our table without our request (similar to nearly all other restaurants) but this was the first restaurant I've ever been to that actually charged for it. Had we known or been forewarned, we would have said no thanks. House bread should be complimentary.

-bk9ruZeK-QbuPxVY5vteA.text: Steaks do not disappoint! Come hungry! Our party of six sampled the filet (melt in your mouth), prime rib ( perfect and served with their homemade horseradish) and salmon (juicy and flavored perfectly). Very generous portions of sides. Onion rings are amazing & were seasoned to give them some heat. Excellent selection of wines and beer. Service was terrific minus our reservation being late. They were accommodating to get us in for our show yet not feel rushed. Would revisit again without question.

3uBewaoBZNonGfNLnNdv4g.text: My second Tom Colicchio restaurant!  And good enough to eat here two nights in a row!  I am a big fan of Beachcraft in Miami Beach, having spent my birthday there this year, so it was a nice surprise to find out Tom Colicchio had another concept in Vegas...of course I had to try it.  Definitely the highlight of both restaurants is the friendly service.  I forgot the name of my bartender/server the first night, but he was absolutely amazing...couldn't have been a nicer gentelman.  The food was also very good.  Had the Filet Mignon and salmon, asparagus, rolls, etc etc...all very tasty and delicious.  Would definitely recommend this place.

3VGIa6BIqT305nGhPuqTLw.text: The home to the best steak I have ever had. Yes, it may have cost me a few dollars more than I would like to spend but worth every penny. It no joke melted in my mouth. Hope to make it back to Craft one day before I kick the bucket. :)

9Gopp-ust9WNmgvR-unZjA.text: We walked in this place at last minute and they kindly seated us even though were in tennis shoes, shorts, and Hurley shirts. I believe our servers name was George. He was very friendly and well presented. He was really knowledgeable of the menu and gave us great recommendations. We ordered braised beef, 16 ounce bone in New York strip, hanger steak, and filet mignon. I also ordered their peppercorn sauce, and we all shared. Each side dish ordered is enough to share with four people. The garlic spinach was fantastic and so was the Cauliflower.  We enjoyed every one of our sakes, but we agreed the 16 ounce bone in New York strip was the best. The braised beef was fantastic and super buttery. I would come back and eat at this restaurant any time without any arguments. I highly recommend.

Ot7oulvYOg7W6IwvI2XdpQ.text: We were very excited to try this restaurant and are steakhouse lovers. Incredibly disappointed by the New York strip to the point of sending it back because it was so tough. I have maybe sent two dishes back myentire life of dining out ,but this meat was terrible. Our waiter was absolutely accommodating and great, giving us a better quality meat, but by the time it came out, the wine was gone and the sides were cold. We still paid the price of the initial inedible cut. When you are spending 400+/couple, you expect better execution of the evening than we experienced. Unfortunately very disappointed and I almost never say that about a dining experience.

MY2VVNrDO52dh-wzvuci3Q.text: Good food, generous proportions, and the staff was very attentive.  If you want to treat yourself to all of the previously mentioned, you should definitely eat here!

pofhueLaYotfMH-mhXgwdQ.text: I recently hosted a business dinner for 10 people on a Friday night at Craftsteak. It was perfect for my event. The steaks were all perfectly cooked. We ordered 6 of the sides and the asparagus was other worldly with a nice spice. The wine was over-priced but that occurs everywhere. Our waiters were friendly and attentive. The oysters as appetizers were very tasty (and I am picky).

ATp8ktC3i9Fz_Mi9SL8NYQ.text: Where do I start? To start, I have never experienced such a lack there of customer service. My boyfriend and I decided to eat wingstop because I have never had it and he had nothing but amazing things to say about their food, service, etc. We ordered our food and the "manager" by the name of Jamilett read us our order back. We ordered 10 wings all flat combo, half original hot and the other half lemon pepper. The other order was 8 boneless with a mix of original hot and bbq. It was correct. We waited about 20 minutes for our food. We get all the way home just to look in the bag to the order being completely wrong. I immediately called the location and spoke to the "manager" once again. She embodied no compassion, nor empathy for our order not being correct. She proceeded to say that she will replace the 5 wings that were supposed to be lemon pepper and re-make the boneless order. By the time we would have waited for that to be re-made, the rest of our food would have been super cold. I explained that to her. Once again, she could careless. She told us that she would not replace nothing else besides what they messed up. By then, I said I'd much rather get a refund and patronize another business instead. My boyfriend and I get back to the location just to be greeted with attitude by the "manager". She told us that she will not give us a refund, nor re-make our food. Highly disappointed by the lack there of compassion. If possible, stay far far away!

El_eP76GxkDjGPfvZJZEzA.text: So wonderful! Our new favorite steak place in Vegas. Everything was wonderful: the bread the tomato salad the potato puree the mushroom the corn and the Steak!  My wife and I both had the domestic wagyu hanger steak. Cooked medium rare. The service was great and they did not constantly bother you but they also did not ignore you. Besides the Steak the corn side was the standout. It just made everything taste better.   My wife and I were too full for dessert but we heard from regulars her that the monkey bread is the way to go if you have room.

-3_8VpjBd0TnMHuxExGqsg.text: The food was great and the wait staff was excellent - we had an amazing meal here!  The only complaint that I have is the noise level. The tables are very close together and I could hear everyone's conversations around us. There were so many people dining, the general noise level was high. There isn't much privacy and it isn't the best for a quiet, romantic dinner. If you don't mind the noise and the hustle bustle, then this place is for you. If you want a quiet, romantic night - this isn't the place.

LDM1T-8ueJUEGsuy7SKIFQ.text: Not sure if it was a lack of consistency or if they just had an off night but compared to the last time I ate here, this time was markedly better. From the apps, to the dessert...the server was a little stand-offish but otherwise, if I had business at Mgm, I would try again.

GI3EKbUZjjPTOs3nFiSJ8w.text: I will eat here again and again. My ribeye steak was tender, buttery and cooked exactly the way I asked. The front of the house rocked. When I asked if the kitchen could provide ice for the leftover steak, Alexander packaged it up and held it in the kitchen while we went to a show. Alexander kept our water glasses topped off and overall provided friendly, exceptional service. From the bartenders to our wait staff, way to go!

VnSCZB0GqyQMN306AUSVGg.text: I visited Vegas last summer and I knew I had to eat at this restaurant being a fan of Top Chef. This is one of the best restaurants I have ever eaten at.   Everything was delicious. The food melts in your mouth and is busting in flavor.   The bread might be the best bread I have ever eaten in my life. 5 stars for the NY strip, ribeye steak, and au gratin potatoes.  The waitstaff is highly professional and took great care of us. This is a can't miss experience. It is worth every penny.

27GQJQ3VlMgeRL_er5QhXA.text: Craftsteak is a very pricey but excellent steakhouse.  It's a beautifully warm, elegant setting, with decor mainly in dark shades, wood, and leather.  There're also beautiful, colorful, lively, fun paintings of cows -- yes, cows -- on the walls over the booths.  The staff is outstanding -- friendly, patient, helpful, knowledgeable, and efficient.  The menu is surprisingly large (I rarely see a menu this size at a place categorized as "fine dining"), as are the portions -- you won't go hungry here without trying, especially if you have a party of four or less and go with the family style option...sooooo much excellent food!  The food has great flavor, especially the meats (of course) and, surprisingly, the bibb salad, which had a light blue-cheese dressing that brought the components together perfectly.  The drinks list is HUGE, with especially extensive wine and scotch sections.  My one issue with Craftsteak is that I felt like it was very overpriced -- even though the quality is excellent -- especially the drinks.  (I knew the bottle prices of a few of the scotches on the list and the markup on a glass seemed ridiculously high to me.)

gZZOS1Pzpfe65AK2KWw1_A.text: Took my man here for his bday last Friday night. Well, he paid, so technically he took me.
